title: national interest dominic cummings stay
story: It is hardly a revelation that Dominic Cummings has many enemies who believe he should be sacked for his alleged infringement of the lockdown rules. He has become a lightning conductor for the anger of a good slice of progressive Britain. They want revenge, above all for Brexit.But the Cummings question raises another interesting question about what, if any, special privileges should be enjoyed by the people running the country on our behalf. There is a kind of hyper-democratic rancour abroad that refuses to contemplate that our rulers, at least while they are ruling, deserve some special treatment.I do not know Mr Cummings personally (and voted Remain in the referendum). Even his fans concede that he can be erratic, and it is reassuring to see, in several decisions that the Government made before the crisis, that his influence is not as great as his enemies imagine. But he is obviously highly capable, science and data literate, and understands many of the failings of the government machine that have been revealed by the crisis (see his 2014 IPPR lecture, “The Hollow Men”). I think it is in the national interest that he stays.   And his case surely sits in a defensible grey zone. Both he and his wife were ill with the virus, placing their child in a vulnerable position. Short of handing the child to social services, it is hard to see what course of action they could have taken but to fall back on family in Durham. And they were, according to reports, fortunate to have the space in Durham to isolate away from Mr Cummings’s parents in a separate cottage, safe in the knowledge they could now rely on family help. They applied human common sense, and their case is in a completely different category to Professor Neil Ferguson’s romantic liaison, or Catherine Calderwood, the former Scottish chief medical officer, who decided to visit her second home. Both of those breaches of lockdown were completely unforced.In general, of course, the law should apply equally to all, and members of the ruling elite should avoid saying one thing and doing another. But there is also widespread agreement that our rulers, and by extension their closest advisers, are entitled to some special treatment. They are, after all, special people, even in democracies – perhaps especially in democracies – and have a very unusual and demanding job, which we want them to perform to the best of their abilities. Boris Johnson clearly did not get normal treatment at St Thomas’ Hospital. Politicians have bodyguards and, to cite a more trivial example, their cars often have police escorts and sail through red lights to get ministers and their advisers to meetings on time. We do, and should, bend the rules for them. The question is, which actions sit legitimately in that ruler privilege zone and which do not? We decided, for example, a few years back, that awarding yourself overgenerous expenses did not (without telling them). There is an anti-elitist piety, often expressed by the academic or media branch of the same broad elite, that refuses to accept the specialness of rulers. I sometimes think that the combination of mass higher education and social media threatens to make society ungovernable. The broad elite is in revolt against the narrow elite. Everyone thinks they know better. We have seen this in freedom of information rules that make it difficult for ministers and officials to have honest conversations, pushing key decisions into private rabbit-holes. (Though it’s a shame the rules were not applied to the scientific advice being given to ministers, where open critique of the science from other scientists would have been useful.)We want transparent, open government, but it has negative unintended consequences that need to be constrained. The transparency requirements of modern institutions encourage a performative, virtue-signalling political culture that makes it harder for people to identify as establishment insiders and come to reasonable compromises.So it’s important that Mr Cummings stays. Even if his actions were technically outside the letter of the law – which is far from clear – there is, surely, an extreme circumstances loophole, and more broadly we need to cut our rulers (and their top advisers) some slack. David Goodhart is author of ‘The Road to Somewhere’ (Penguin)More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: next two months lockdown questions answered
story: Two months ago, Britain went into lockdown. Our freedoms were curtailed, and the simple pleasures we have known of socialising with friends and family, walking along a beach or playing a game of five-a-side in the park stopped overnight. Life was put on hold. Now, with a gradual easing of the measures, there is the tantalising prospect of a return to some sort of normality. But how much will life go back to the way it was? Here, with the help of our team of  writers, we try to explain what the next two months of lockdown will look like. The hot weather as we enter summer brings with it thoughts of BBQs and beers with friends and family, but although people are able to have BBQs in their garden, these can only involve members of their own household at the moment. Mass gatherings and visiting friends or family are still prohibited in England, Scotland and Wales, meaning BBQs with friends and family are not permitted. Loosening restrictions will depend on which stage the Government’s five-level alert system is at - the more the virus is contained, the more rules will be relaxed. Currently Britain is transitioning from level 4 to level 3. Scotland hopes to move to phase one of its own exit roadmap after May 28. Meetings of two households will be allowed in small numbers, which would permit BBQs in gardens under this arrangement and with physical distancing. Larger groups from two different households will be permitted to meet outside under phase two later in the year.Elsewhere, ministers are hoping to continue to ease measures in the coming weeks and months, meaning BBQs with people outside of someone’s immediate household could be a possibility by the August bank holiday. Relaxations are to be assessed on a fortnightly basis, and socially-distanced BBQs could be permitted in line with the safe reopening of bars and restaurants, currently scheduled for July 4.One model currently being implemented in other countries is that of ‘social bubbles’, where people are able to spend time with a maximum number of people from outside their household. It is advised that this takes place in gardens or on terraces where possible.In Belgium, each household is currently allowed to invite up to four guests, all of whom are expected to remain 1.5 metres apart and observe other preventative measures such as regular hand-washing. If a similar policy were to be introduced in Britain, it would mean you could have a socially-distant barbecue with a limited number of friends or relatives.As bars and restaurants across the world reopen (Italians were allowed to eat out last Monday for the first time in months), Britons are asking themselves when they’ll be able to get in on the act. Many of our pubs and restaurants have begun tentatively reopening – for takeaway and delivery only. These include high-street chains such as McDonald's, which has started reopening its drive-thru restaurants in large numbers.So when will we be able to eat and drink inside a pub or restaurant? The latest official advice is that “at least some” hospitality venues will be able to reopen from July 4 at the earliest, as part of the next phase of the lockdown exit plan, but only if the number of infections and deaths continues on the same trajectory. However, the experience is likely to be very different to pre-Covid days, according to the latest draft guidelines. Safety measures may include no bar service (and no drinking at the bar) PPE for staff no salt and pepper shakers or table menus cashless service and tables restricted to household members. At all food and drink establishments, some form of social distancing is likely to be in place, although the British Beer and Pub Association is pushing for the current two-metre recommended distance to be reduced to one metre (in line with WHO guidelines), which would allow businesses to serve a much larger number of customers. Many restaurants operate within tight margins, and some industry figures have warned that it may not be viable to open for business if they are forced to keep their premises half empty.However, if the Government listens to the recommendations of Sunetra Gupta, Professor of Theoretical Epidemiology at the University of Oxford, the hospitality industry could be back to normal much sooner than expected. She suggested this week that pubs and restaurants could reopen tomorrow without posing the threat of a second wave of coronavirus. It's safe to say your trip will not be business as usual - we've outlined in depth what will change here. The furlough scheme has been a life raft keeping millions of Britons from plunging into financial hardship during the pandemic - but the Government has made it clear that it cannot afford to keep it running indefinitely. More than eight million people are now furloughed and are receiving their wages via the Job Retention Scheme, costing the Government £11.1 billion so far. Hundreds of thousands of extra workers have been added every week since the Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, pledged to pay 80 per cent of people’s wages up to £2,500 a month. Despite the generous support package, more than two million are already jobless and there are fears that this figure will continue on its upwards trend throughout the summer. Mr Sunak has extended the furlough scheme by four months to the end of October, but then businesses will have to make tough decisions for the future of their employees and many could find themselves out of a job.From the start of August, the scheme will become more flexible, allowing employees to bring furloughed employees back part-time.Workers will continue to receive the same level of support at 80 per cent of their current salary up to £2,500 a month, but employers will need to share the burden of paying salaries with the Government. Further details are yet to be published but are expected for the end of May. Your employer can end your furlough period at any time if they need you back at work, so long as you have been away for more than three weeks.  They can also make you redundant when you are on furlough. If you feel that you would like to extend your furlough period because you are at risk, there is nothing stopping you from asking. But remember employers have no obligation to enact this. If they do ask you to go back into work but you need to self-isolate then you will have to claim statutory sick pay.You may find that you are put on furlough until the very end of the scheme, at which point your employer will either get you back to work or could make you redundant. If you do find yourself being made redundant, you may be eligible for certain things, including redundancy pay, a notice period, a consultation with your employer, the option to move into a different job and time off to find a new job. You can then look into applying for universal credit and jobseeker’s allowance. Despite an increase in companies promoting flexible working over the past decade, just 5 per cent of Britain’s 33 million employees mainly worked from home last year, according to ONS data, with an additional 27 per cent occasionally doing so.This has risen since the Covid-19 outbreak, with 44.6 per cent of workers surveyed by the ONS saying they had worked from home during one week in April.Post-Covid, employment lawyers believe it will be difficult for companies to refuse applications from staff wishing to work from home. A law change in Britain in 2014 means that employees have the right to make one “flexibility request” per year, regardless of their reasons for doing so, and the employer has a legal duty to consider it. Previously, the law stated that only parents of children under 16 or those registered as carers were allowed to request flexible working.Those who do go back to the office, through choice or necessity, will face a very different environment to what they’re accustomed to. Office spaces will be considerably downsized as employers seek to cut costs, social distancing requirements mean floor markings and plastic screens will be installed, while some firms are considering additional methods such as using thermal imaging screens in their reception areas to determine the body temperature of anyone entering the building.Staff are likely to work in shift patterns spread over a seven-day working week, with offices half occupied to ensure sufficient distance between colleagues.When might workers return to the office? It could be a while yet. Boris Johnson has encouraged people who cannot work from home, such as those in construction or manufacturing, to return to work now. However, an email addressed to civil servants and disclosed by Sky News explained that those currently working from home could still be doing so for another six to 12 months.Sally Peck, Family and Education Editor The next two months will bring us to what would be the end of this academic year for schools. But it will look nothing like summer term as we have known it.The Government roadmap calls for the ‘conditional’ reopening of primary schools from June 1, beginning with children in Reception, and Years 1 and 6, but in smaller class sizes to ensure that social distancing can be implemented. All primary-aged children will return to school “before the summer for a month if feasible”, the dossier adds, although it acknowledges this will be determined by whether coronavirus cases stay low. However, on May 20, just a week and a half before schools are set to open their doors, the Justice Secretary acknowledged that the country is ided over the reopening of schools. And teaching unions have responded with a list of demands before they advise their members to return to work. Many parents have said that they will not send their children back to school until September at the earliest, and it seems unlikely that most primary or secondary pupils will spend much time in classrooms in June or July.Few secondary pupils will see the inside of a classroom over the next two months: while Years 10 and 12 were told to prepare for some “face-to-face contact”, as these groups are one year away from sitting crucial GCSE and A-level exams, the rest are unlikely to return.And for any children who do return, it’s pretty clear that they won’t be getting a normal experience: teachers won’t be delivering the normal curriculum to small groups of children they’re more likely to be focusing on emotional resilience, doing what they can to prepare young people for a different phase of education.Private schools operate independently and may make their own decisions about when to return to the classroom, but the vast majority have followed government guidelines for state schools, and intend to keep the bulk of children learning online for the rest of this academic year.Universities are continuing to operate from a distance through the end of their terms in June, and some have said that lectures will remain online-only when students start the new academic year in autumn.Oliver Smith, Assistant Head of Travel The Government’s “strategy” on post-lockdown travel has been an utter shambles. It is almost June and still we have no clear idea about whether we will be able to go on an overseas holiday this summer. UK airlines, including easyJet and BA, are getting ready to resume services (don’t forget your face mask), and over in Europe, there are signs of hope. Greece (which will welcome visitors to Athens from June 15, and to its islands from July 1), Italy (which will kickstart tourism on June 3) and Spain (where the sector is planning a late June relaunch) are all easing travel restrictions. But in Britain, we are closing the door. After weeks without guidance, Boris Johnson dropped a bombshell on May 10 when he signalled that the UK was preparing to impose a two-week period of self-isolation on all international arrivals, including returning holidaymakers. This bizarre decision, a fine example of shutting the door (two months) after the horse has bolted, has been widely ridiculed. The peak is long gone, Covid cases across Europe are rapidly disappearing, and our neighbours are opening their doors - so why the devil are we raising the drawbridge?It is also unworkable. Fines of £1,000 have been threatened for those who break the rules, and police say they will carry out 100 spot checks a day. But with Heathrow alone handling 80 million passengers a year, the odds of being caught look exceptionally slim. Furthermore, Ireland, as part of the Common Travel Area, is exempt from the policy. So holidaymakers could simply fly to the Costa del Sol via Dublin and dodge the quarantine. Grant Shapps added to the confusion with his “air bridges” proposal, and in the meantime, with the Foreign Office still issuing its indefinite ban on travel, tour operators and airlines are slowly sinking under a tide of refund requests. As for UK holidays, struggling hotels, campsites and B&ampBs are clinging to the prospect of a July 4 restart. The Prime Minister has said that some hospitality businesses should be able to reopen from then, but detail is severely lacking and the “stay away” attitudes of regional authorities are far from encouraging. So what will happen in the next 60 days? Even if a quarantine is put in place, most are predicting it will only last a matter of weeks, or be replaced by more nuanced restrictions on arrivals from certain destinations. As for the Foreign Office advice against overseas travel, it was introduced when countries around the world began putting restrictions on overseas arrivals. So it seems reasonable to assume that, once destinations begin welcoming tourists, those advisories will be lifted one by one.Therefore, an overseas July or August holiday remains an outside possibility. But the idea of millions of us crowding into airports, packing onto flights and heading for teeming beaches and buzzing bars and restaurants of the Med seems very unlikely.Flights will be slow to restart, and many of us will be reticent to travel. Those that get away may find some cracking deals, but their holiday will be a strange one: expect temperature checks in airports, mandatory face masks on planes, and social distancing in museums and restaurants. A trip to a remote national park might be more appealing than a city break. And, while some Caribbean islands like St Lucia are tentatively reopening to tourists, long-haul travel looks unlikely until much later in the year.In terms of domestic travel, I’d be shocked if hotels - or, at the very least, campsites and self-catering properties - are not given the green light to reopen in July. Firms are already reporting a surge in summer bookings and staycations are already happening in many European countries (and without any sign of an uptick in coronavirus cases).Should the Government decide to block UK holidays as well as foreign ones this summer, while the rest of Europe is enjoying seaside breaks, it should expect some very disgruntled citizens. Hairdressers are provisionally set to open on July 4, along with other hospitality services. Although there are no firm rules on how they'll have to reopen, it’s likely given the close-contact nature of salons that they’ll have to operate under strict social distancing rules.For your first visit back into a hairdresser in July, every appointment will have to be made online or over the phone, you’ll probably be required to wear a mask and some services such as blow-dries will likely be off the menu, too. Your hairdresser will be wearing full PPE and you may have to pre-pay for your appointment from home, to limit contact. Here are eight things to expect on your first visit back. If you’re keen on a haircut as soon as your hairdresser reopens, many have started waiting lists on their websites, so get it touch. Bethan Holt, Director of Fashion News and Features DirectorThe good news is that you can still shop online now - and that’s been a lifeline for retailers big and small - but there’s certainly nothing quite like a trip to the shops. The government has announced that non-essential retailers, like fashion stores, can begin to re-open from June 1. And many are preparing to do just that. The queues and crowds which formed outside the likes of Zara and TJ Maxx in Europe and the US last week show many of us are eager to get back to browsing.But the truth is, it’s not going to be like a shopping trip of yore - no more piling into a changing room with piles to try on, crowding around the tills to check out and browsing in big groups.  Most retailers will keep changing rooms closed, with social distancing measures in place and hand sanitizer free-flowing. There are ingenious tech solutions in the offing to help keep hygiene standards high - clothes will be frequently steamed or treated with UV lights to kill germs. Not all shops will be open from the start of June. Luxe knitwear retailer Brora says it plans to start with its shops in the North first while footwear label Kurt Geiger will open just 10-20 of its outposts at first. It says that the safety measures it’s bringing in will cost £75,000 per year, per store.If you’re nervous about the prospect of hitting the shops, then smaller boutiques and independent retailers still have plenty of solutions. At Me + Em, you can book in styling sessions via Zoom, and the Notting Hill boutique Couverture and the Garbstore has offered out of hours private shopping appointments for anyone not wishing to share a confined space with other customers. Many more local boutiques are considering equally ingenious ways to enable devotees to shop safely.  Still have questions before heading to the shops? Our experts have answered your questions. The Government’s roadmap for leaving lockdown makes it clear that the reopening of gyms comes some way down the line, after outdoor spaces such as tennis clubs and golf clubs, where the risk of transmission is far lower.The document says it is the Government's ambition to start reopening other leisure facilities from July 4 at the earliest, but stresses that it is likely that reopening indoor public spaces such as leisure centres and gyms, along with venues that attract large crowds like sports stadia, may only be possible significantly later, depending on the reduction in numbers of infections.Though gyms remain closed, people are now permitted to exercise outside as many times each day as they wish since coronavirus is less likely to spread outdoors. Outdoor gyms and playgrounds remain closed, since there is a higher risk of close contact and touching surfaces.Can't picture how gyms would work with social distancing measures? We take a look here. At present, wedding ceremonies are not taking place in the UK. While the Government has not yet announced its plans for ceremonies going forward, they get a brief mention in the “Our Plan to Rebuild” dossier: “The Government is also examining how to enable people to gather in slightly larger groups to better facilitate small weddings.” Exactly how small these ceremonies will be has yet to be decided.If you have a wedding planned in June, July or August, should you postpone? “Absolutely,” says wedding planner Katrina Otter, because the “guidelines are still uncertain.” Most of Otter’s clients have postponed to September or next year.While Otter is “hopeful for September onwards”, she says it might be safer to postpone your wedding until 2021. “The issue is that, yes, it might be that the weddings are allowed to take place but with social distancing measures in place,” she says. “There is also the very real risk that if we go over the R value, that we will suddenly be told we’re going back to isolation – and the wedding’s tomorrow. There’s always that ‘what if?’ hanging over the couple.”Some couples might opt for “alternative” ceremonies on Zoom, even when the restrictions are lifted, but this won't suit everyone. “It’s going to work for some couples,” Otter says. “It’s definitely not going to work for the majority.”From booking bigger venues to socially distanced ceremonies, here's what future brides and grooms can expect on their big day. Scientists in the UK and across the globe are working at an unprecedented pace to develop diagnostics, treatments and vaccines to tackle the coronavirus - and good news is starting to emerge in all three areas.In the UK swab tests, to determine if a person has an active Covid-19 infection, are now available for everyone over the age of five, while the Government this week signed contracts with Roche Diagnostics and Abbott Laboratories to roll out 10 million antibody blood tests in the coming months. These tests are used to determine whether someone has been infected in the past and will help track the prevalence of the virus across the country.From next week these will be offered to some NHS and care staff in England, plus certain patients and care residents. While experts believe that the presence of antibodies in our blood is likely to confer immunity to Covid-19, this is yet to be confirmed.On treatments, the focus has been on repurposing existing drugs and some - such as an antiviral called remdesivir - have shown promise. Experts are eagerly awaiting the upcoming results of three ‘mega-trials’ - including the Recovery trial in the UK, for more conclusive evidence. This could come as soon as the end of June.The final, most critical, tool is a vaccine. Currently more than 100 candidates are in development globally, with at least eight already being tested in people.This week Moderna, an American biotech, announced promising early results of a safety trial of its vaccine in eight volunteers. In the UK, Imperial College and Oxford University are both developing vaccines that are seen as the front runners, with the latter now entering the second phase of human trials.AstraZeneca and Oxford will produce 100 million doses of their vaccine, including 30million for the UK, which they claim could be available by September - but even if we have a safe, effective vaccine it could take months and months to manufacture at scale. Experts have also warned against over-optimism. While the majority say there is a “good chance” that a vaccine will be developed, there is no guarantee.For English property, the next two months will be a process of adjustment. The Government’s surprise reopening of the housing market on May 13 means that buyers can go to house viewings, sellers can list properties and agents are reopening their offices. The new guidance is complex. Sellers must clean surfaces, open doors, provide places for buyers to wash their hands and then ideally vacate their homes for viewings. In two months’ time, virtual viewing technology will have boomed. Surveyors, valuers and conveyancers will have returned employees from furlough and should have made headway through the backlog that built up over the seven-week freeze.The rules are different in the other countries that make up the UK. The Scottish Government has said the property market there should be able to reopen from June 18. It is reasonable to assume that Wales and Northern Ireland’s housing markets are likely to follow similar timelines, but for now all three markets are shut. Anyone thinking about moving house in the coming months should be wary of the fact that the market could be suspended again. There is a note in the English Government’s guidance that sales could be refrozen if the coronavirus outbreak does not stay under control.Buyers in the English market are already trying hard to renegotiate big discounts, in light of the Bank of England’s expectation that house prices could fall by 16 per cent. Knight Frank estimates that values have dipped by 5 per cent  since lockdown began. But even in two months, the economic impact of coronavirus and rising unemployment on prices will not be fully felt. There are two protective cushions around house prices. The furlough scheme, which is supporting the wages of nearly eight million people, and mortgage holidays, which are currently being used by one in seven households. When these end, more sellers will be under pressure to accept low-ball offers. But for now, both schemes have been extended until the autumn. In July, the real problems for the housing market will still be yet to come.Britain is in the deepest recession for 300 years. The lockdown has closed swathes of the economy, furloughed 8million workers, and left the survival of entire industries in doubt.But businesses are fighting back. Factories and construction sites have led the way in working out how to reopen safely. Shops are planning to spring back to life with social distancing in place. Office staff have proved remarkably adaptable to working from the kitchen table. It means the very worst could be over already.Around one-third of the economy was closed in April, so the gradual reopening means growth should return tentatively into May. GDP fell by 2 per cent in the first quarter and is set to fall by as much as 20 per cent in the second quarter, matching the usual definition of a recession as two consecutive quarters of shrinking GDP.With the reopening going ahead, that means this extreme recession will be over almost as soon as it began. That is the good news.The bad news is that it will take far longer to get the economy back up to its pre-coronavirus size. Jobs and businesses can still rely on government support for now.But that will not last forever. From August employers will be expected to chip in to the cost of furloughing their workers.That means they have two months to draw up plans to pay those costs, with more firms reopening to test out customer demand, and their ability to cope with social distancing.The hospitality trade, for instance, expects to be able to reopen with around 30 per cent of its usual capacity, with limits on the number of customers and staff allowed in at any one time.By the end of the year the industry expects to get up to the 60 per cent or so of usual revenues which should enable most firms to break even.But that is a long time to operate at a loss, and might mean more staff are laid off. The strain on businesses and family finances is just beginning, even if the ‘official’ recession may soon be over.The UK and the EU's visions for the future trading relationship after Brexit are so different, there is little optimism that the next two months will bring a breakthrough. The last round of trade negotiations ended in acrimony and mutual recrimination last week.Britain has responded by publishing its draft trade deal and fisheries agreement, which are negotiating documents that had been secret until now. Relations are chilly.  What is on offer is not a fair free trade agreement between close economic partners but a relatively low quality trade agreement coming with unprecedented EU oversight of our laws and institutions, David Frost, the UK's chief negotiator, wrote to Michel Barnier on Tuesday.The two sides are particularly ided over fishing and the EU's demand for level playing field guarantees. The deadline to finalise the trade deal is the end of the Brexit transition period at the end of the year. Unless the deal is struck or the transition period is extended, which has been ruled out by Downing Street, the UK will be trading on less advantageous WTO terms with its major trading partner from Jan 1. The clock is ticking and the coronavirus pandemic has slowed the negotiations, forcing them online and at one point both chief negotiators into quarantine. The next crunch point is June when the UK and EU meet to evaluate progress and potentially discuss extension. There is one negotiating round in June before the high level meeting but with both sides telling the other they need to change their red lines, there seems no chance of the impasse being broken. UK sources have suggested they could walk away from the negotiating table if not enough progress is made and begin preparing for no deal. Suggestions that Boris Johnson could get personally involved in the talks and EU leaders could intervene to break the deadlocked negotiations are treated cautiously in Brussels. Diplomats point out that the June EU summit, where any compromise could be agreed by the bloc's heads of state and government, will be dominated by a brewing row over how best to kickstart Europe's economic recovery after coronavirus. German football’s Bundesliga was the first major European sports league back earlier this month and there are plans across English sport for a gradual and restricted resumption of competition in June and July.The Government has published ‘Step One’ proposals for returning to training and some sports, including Premier League football teams, began socially distanced training this week. The players and staff will be tested twice a week for Covid-19 and clubs hope to move imminently to full contact training before then resuming matches from around the middle of June. Matches, though, would be held without crowds and fans are unlikely to be permitted at matches until at least 2021. This leaves huge doubt over the financial viability of football at every level below the Premier League, which is largely funded by broadcast income.Other sports are also working towards their return. England’s cricket series this summer against the West Indies and India are still being planned without fans, rugby union hopes to begin its Premiership in July while golf’s European Tour intends to stage five tournaments in England and Wales this summer.June is the earliest that any sport can resume and the first back is likely to be snooker, who are planning an 11-day tournament on ITV from June 1 that will be staged without fans in Milton Keynes.  All players, staff and contractors must return a negative coronavirus test prior to entering the venue, which has been selected because there is accommodation on site. Horse racing also plans to resume without fans at Newcastle on June 1, just a few hours after the Championship League Snooker begins.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: oxford university covid 19 vaccine trial has 50 per cent chance
story: It began in January as a “little lab project” after a curious new disease emerged in China.Little more than four months later, the eyes of the nation - and perhaps the world - are firmly upon Professor Adrian Hill and his team at Oxford University.This week, the pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca announced a $1.2 billion deal with the US government to produce 400 million doses of the unproven coronavirus vaccine first produced in Prof Hill's Oxford lab.Meanwhile, the British Government has agreed to pay for up to 100 million doses, adding that 30 million may be ready for UK citizens by September.The stakes could hardly be higher. If proven effective, the ZD1222 vaccine would allow people to leave their homes, go back to work, and rebuild the economy.But Professor Hill, director of the university’s Jenner Institute, revealed that his team now faces a major problem, throwing the September deadline into doubt.In short, their adversary is disappearing so rapidly in the UK that the next phase of trials has only a 50 per cent chance of success.Without Covid-19 spreading in the community, volunteers will not catch the disease, leaving scientists unable to prove that their vaccine makes any difference.Professor Hill said that of 10,000 people recruited to test the vaccine in the coming weeks - some of whom will be given a placebo - he expected fewer than 50 people to catch the virus. If fewer than 20 test positive, then the results may be useless, he warned.“It is a race, yes. But it's not a race against the other guys. It's a race against the virus disappearing, and against time,” Professor Hill, 61, told the  from his university laboratory, long emptied by the lockdown.“We said earlier in the year that there was an 80 per cent chance of developing an effective vaccine by September.“But at the moment, there’s a 50 per cent chance that we get no result at all.“We’re in the bizarre position of wanting Covid to stay, at least for a little while. But cases are declining.At the Downing Street press conference on May 17, Business Secretary Alok Sharma suggested half the UK population could be given the jab this autumn, should it prove effective.But Prof Hill said success was far from guaranteed, and warned against “over-promising”.“I wouldn’t book a holiday in October on the back of these announcements, put it that way,” he said.“The number keeps going up. Thirty million doses is quite hard, and one hundred million is harder still by September. Remember, even if we get a result in August, we can't start vaccinating everyone the next day.” “There’s a danger of over-promising here. This is the way I usually say it: this is our ambition. There are multiple risks. It's never been done before. We don't know if we can do it. We think we can. You know, mistakes happen. Accidents happen in cooking as well. That needs to be understood.”Early next month, Oxford will release the crucial results of a first trial of more than 1,000 UK volunteers conducted in April, when the disease was at its peak.“The first trial is going fine. We’re still in business, I can tell you that,” Prof Hill said.“But we’re not going to do what others have done - say we’ve got something good, but we’re not showing you yet. That’s just bonkers. You either disclose your results or you don’t.”Around the world, eight potential Covid-19 vaccines have gone to human trials: four in China, two in the US, and one in Germany. Many of those teams - including Oxford - are planning to move their next trials to Covid-19 hotspots overseas, but that will take time. The Oxford team has already arranged further trials in the US, and are in talks with other countries where the virus is still spreading.“You think we've got a problem? Prof Hill said. What would you do if you were in China? There are three Chinese companies looking for phase three and there’s no Covid in China. So what do they do?The Oxford team had a strong head start on their rivals. Most of the other scientists searching for a vaccine across the world have been forced to hold small clinical trials to prove their treatment is safe. But the Jenner Institute already had a vaccine tested against an earlier coronavirus, which was proven to be harmless to humans.The technique grew from Prof Hill’s search for a vaccine to combat malaria, a scourge he first witnessed in the 1980s while visiting an uncle working as a priest in a war-torn part of modern Zimbabwe.Over the past two decades, the Jenner Institute learned how to alter the genetic code of a familiar virus, first to neutralise its harmful effects, and then to make it imitate a deadlier disease. Injected into the bloodstream, the harmless virus can induce the body to produce an immune response, providing long-lasting protection.Prof Hill's long search for a viable malaria vaccine has so far been fruitless, despite more than 70 clinical trials. But last year, his colleague Professor Sarah Gilbert modified the same chimpanzee virus to vaccinate against MERS, a coronavirus, which then passed human trials in the UK. When Covid-19 began to spread, Prof Gilbert decided to do a “little lab project” to see whether the Oxford technique could work on the new disease. Tests were promising, and in April six rhesus macaque monkeys were given single doses of the Oxford vaccine at a US lab, and were then exposed to the virus. A month later, all six monkeys were still healthy.If the next phase of human trials is a success, the Government has pledged that “people in the UK will get the first access, helping to protect thousands of lives”.Next in line will be the US government, which has secured 300m doses to protect its own citizens, under Donald Trump’s so-called ‘Warp Speed’ programme.But Prof Hill said Oxford University had secured “hardwired” assurances against so-called 'vaccine nationalism' - the prioritisation of treatment toward rich Western nations at the expense of others.“The reputational damage to the university would be enormous if we provided the vaccine only for the UK and US and not for the rest of those countries of the world where it's very likely the pandemic would still be raging,” he said.“I’ve been thinking about it day and night for weeks. We care about Africa. We know the people there. We know there's going to be a significant problem at some stage. Brazil looks terrible and India is getting there fast.“The vaccine should be supplied to the countries of greatest need at the moment that it works, rather than the countries who got there first. And that will happen.”A deal has already been signed with the Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine producer. If the Oxford vaccine works, Prof Hill said he would be happy for other countries to use his research principles to protect their own citizens.“We might feel a little peculiar about that. We got there first, but everyone else piles in. We might feel that we've done the heavy lifting. “But actually we wouldn't care. We're not competing in a cutthroat way. If someone else can produce a billion doses, we’ll have a party.”Despite the billion dollar price tag, Oxford will not be making vast amounts of money from the breakthrough, Prof Hill insisted.Simple arithmetic will tell you that there’s no money being made by the university. It’s pretty amazing that it can be manufactured at that selling price. We’re coming clean and saying: during the pandemic, we will not make money.” Until last week, the Oxford vaccine was considered the clear frontrunner in the global race. Last week, however, a widely-reported article in Forbes cast doubt on the results of the monkey trial, suggesting that results actually showed the vaccine did not prevent the animals from catching or spreading the virus because traces were found in the creatures’ noses.Prof Hill said the article was misleading because the monkeys had been deliberately “overdosed” on coronavirus in order to test for safety.“The honest truth, I think, is that the author is a long-retired senior Harvard virologist, infectious disease guy. He's not a vaccine developer,” he said.“We used a really high dose and these guys gave it not just into the lungs and the nose. They gave it into the mouth, and they gave it into the eyes. They gave a huge dose. I mean, seriously, it’s that level of basic.”Even so, Prof Hill accepts the chances of success still hang firmly in the balance.“The US government, the UK government, loads of charities and philanthropists are all saying we’ll pay to have it manufactured, before you finish the trial. I mean, it's a huge kind of vote of confidence in what we're doing. It's really flattering,” he said.“But that doesn't guarantee the result. It could be nothing or could be great or somewhere in between.We're conflicted. We believe in our technology, and I suppose we're more likely to overestimate than underestimate. “We try to be as objective as we can, but we spent 16 years developing this technology. If it suddenly looks like it might be useful to the whole world, you really want it to work.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: portrait nation lockdown telegraph readers share touching stories
story: It has been two months since Boris Johnson put Britain into a full-scale lockdown, and there have been drastic changes to how we live our lives. Workplaces, restaurants and bars have had to shut their doors, and many people have not had any contact with their loved ones for months.We've spoken to some of our readers to paint a picture of Britain during lockdown. We were told stories of heartbreak, loneliness and despair, but also tales of hope and compassion. Read on to see how the lives of your fellow readers have changed in lockdown and share your own stories in the comments section below.I was diagnosed with breast cancer only weeks before lockdown and I am totally alone in a small flat with no outside space. My GP has failed to identify me as vulnerable. I'm dealing with chemotherapy and abject loneliness.The significant life-changing aspects of lockdown include the realisation that I am unimportant to even my immediate family. WhatsApp conversations are superficial. The effects of chemotherapy mean that eating and getting fresh fruit and vegetables is impossible except for the few days following a hallowed supermarket delivery.My finances are shot and will take some years to address. Years spent supporting everyone else now seem futile as no one else has stepped forward. I take a daily walk and in all these weeks only two people have smiled at me and one of those said hello, from a distance of course. A sign of things to come?With my compromised immune system, I am shielded from infections of all kinds. I can, and will, cope with what life is throwing at me. I have been supported to get to my treatment appointments by selfless community transport drivers who give me much-needed conversation if only for a few minutes.The most significant change has been that my mum celebrated her 100th birthday on May 16 and I couldn't even visit her in her care home. I was her carer for years before she had to go into the home at Christmas in 2015 and visits to her were the focus of my life.Paul Seymour, an NHS worker who caught coronavirus: Both my wife Joanne and I work in a hospital, she is a senior midwife and I am a clinical systems manager. When this crisis hit, I had just developed Covid-19 symptoms. At first, my symptoms were mild but it got a lot worse, so much so that I even recorded a 'farewell video' for my wife 'just in case'.However, I was lucky enough to already have remote access to the hospital systems and, apart from one day when I felt so ill that I couldn't get out of bed at all, I was able to continue working. If I'm honest, this also helped keep me occupied and active, with the added benefit that I could take breaks and relax whenever I felt fatigued and then resume working afterwards.Shortly after a period of isolation, I was told that I would need to work from home for three months. I have numerous health conditions, including angina, six coronary stents and diabetes, but I am expecting to return to work and the hospital on June 15.My wife of course has continued to work very long hours and has had to cancel her annual leave. The big change back for us, when it finally happens, will be the ability to finally get away from it all and relax, she has been tireless in her dedication and really needs a break away from it all!For me at least, 'lockdown' has been a mostly positive experience, which would not have been possible if the technology wasn't available. I've also taken to trying to brighten things up during 'virtual meetings' – only with members of my own team of course!Every year the hospital hosts a staff awards ceremony.  I’m on the awards committee and I try to let my hair down each year, even though I don’t really have any nowadays. I really hope the event goes ahead this year as it will be needed more than ever as it celebrates the wonderful staff and all that they do - they’ve always been heroes to me.I am a single parent and full-time carer to my children. We go out and about a lot - to parks and playgrounds, the beach, swimming. All of our activities had to stop and all of a sudden we were protecting a vulnerable person in a dark house with no garden.All of our family coping strategies involve the freedom of outdoor space and the ability to shake off the rules, yet suddenly the outdoors became a danger zone where we couldn’t touch or play or mingle and an invisible threat surrounded us. I very much look forward to the day that we can once again fully immerse ourselves in the freedom of nature without the undercurrent of fear.The greatest positives for our family is the time we have had to play games and learn together. Without the rush and the scheduling we have done more as a threesome and the bond between siblings is growing as they turn to each other to play, in the absence of school, nursery and friends.For me, having never sewn in my life, I gave into an impulse to buy a sewing machine and have discovered a great pleasure in creating clothes for my children. It’s particularly satisfying to make things that are impossible to buy for my daughter, who has atypical proportions as a result of her disability. It would have been far easier to support my son’s emotions if he had had a safe place to let off steam rather than having to wait until we could leave the house for exercise. I think he has felt the most caged in and I have had moments of overwhelming, crushing claustrophobia.I was told to work from home ‘for the foreseeable future’ in March, due to being 13 weeks' pregnant, and I have been working from home ever since. My husband works in motorsport but was made redundant due to the factory closing down. He is a contractor so isn’t covered by any of the employee retention schemes.I work for the NHS so I am lucky that I can work from home and keep my job, but my life has changed dramatically forever as I am pregnant with a low income, an unemployed husband, three dogs to feed and a baby on the way. If my husband can’t get a job in the next two months, I fear we will be unable to pay our mortgage and therefore lose the house.This is a miracle pregnancy and I have been unable to see my family since the beginning of February. They live 150 miles away and not being able to be with them during my pregnancy has been really challenging and upsetting. The only positive to the lockdown is the positive impact it is having on the environment around the globe. Seeing wildlife flourish is great.I'm a fundraising manager for the Royal Hospital for Neuro-disability in Putney. When the lockdown began I was required to work from home, but the hospital asked for staff volunteers willing to help out during the crisis. I signed up and for the past two months I have been running the hospital's uniform control, distributing clean uniforms and scrubs to front-line staff. I do that for three hours in the morning and then return home to do my regular job.Not seeing my regular group of friends has been very challenging and some friendships have definitely fallen by the wayside during lockdown. But volunteering means I've met so many more people than I would have done had I just stuck to doing my regular job from home. Having that opportunity has helped me to maintain my mental wellbeing too.The most positive outcome of my experience has been the overwhelming support the hospital has received from the wider community. They have come together to help us through the difficulties we faced sourcing PPE. In particular, local community groups and churches have been able to provide us with over 200 sets of handmade scrubs for front-line staff. One lady donated a set featuring Marvel superheroes, which she made from a duvet cover given to her by her neighbour's young son. Without all the hard work of these community volunteers we would have really struggled to provide appropriate clothing for staff working on wards.Jane Dean, a volunteer from Highcliffe:I now appreciate the simple pleasures in life, like a sunny day and walking to the sea. I’ve really connected with my neighbours and the community spirit has given me hope for a more promising, kinder future.On VE Day 75 my neighbours got together to celebrate, remember and comfort one another. We marked the end of one crisis while managing this current one! We decorated our road in red, white and blue, drank wine and danced at a distance. If this is our new normal and a glimpse of our future, then it’s restored my faith in mankind as there is so much good and compassion in people.I live in Highcliffe and work voluntary for a group called Highcliffe Action Team. Our Facebook page #LoveHighcliffe features images and posts of what’s been taking place in and around our village. This includes our local bakery working 20 hours to make enough bread to serve and supply the community and our butcher getting up at 4 a.m. to produce thousands of his award-winning pork sausages. A tree in our local health centre has been decorated with hearts, rainbow cutouts and messages of thanks. Our beach is littered with pebbles and stones painted by children with well wishes and love. In the words of the late, great Louis Armstrong 'It’s A Wonderful World'.Hannah, the mother to a Generation C baby:My son was born on March 26 and he is classed as a Generation C baby. While I've had my partner and daughter at home with me, my family haven't met my son properly yet. It has been a tough few weeks without the support of my mum and sister.A positive of lockdown has been the time that we have had with our son to bond and spending time at home with my daughter that I'll probably never have again.Eugene Roberts, a 63-year-old Briton in Catalonia:We have spent 67 days, so far, in lockdown in Catalonia as we have a home here. Our dog was injured in February so we could not repatriate ourselves to the UK as he was not fit to travel at lockdown. Our son, wife and grandson (15 months old) live in Barcelona but we have been separated throughout this period.Our village of 1,200 residents has been hard-hit by Covid-19. We have been desperate to stay well, to avoid hospital, where my 65- year-old husband and myself (63 years old) would have been separated and unable to easily communicate with staff.The town hall staff have been amazing, communicating every day to tell us about the latest government and health information, balcony concerts, local suppliers making home deliveries and coordinating sewers, including myself, to make masks and gowns for the hospital and care facilities in and around our nearest large town.Our Catalan neighbours have also been brilliant, buying us fresh milk for our 'English tea' and checking if we needed anything. Being in lockdown, in solidarity, when they thought we would probably 'run for home' has helped us find acceptance here. We now feel safe and part of this wonderful community. We have discovered Zoom, so it has been wonderful to feel almost like your family and friends are in the room with you. We have watched more ballet and theatre performances, via YouTube, and I enjoyed sewing masks, albeit alone, but feeling I was contributing in the only way I could without being able to fluently speak Catalan.My husband retired at the start of lockdown and this lengthy period of stillness has helped him handle the transition from a hectic business life to a slower pace, I think. The biggest challenges have been cooking from a freezer and larder which only gets restocked every  two-three weeks, losing internet for three days but most the challenging aspect has not being able to see and cuddle our grandson.A lot has changed for me. I now work as a home-based educational support worker. My role used to involve a lot of face-to-face interaction and being around a lot of people, all of the time. I used to drive to work. Now, I help students attend virtual lessons. I contact new students with support needs and try to offer support and reassurance, without being able to give a clear picture of what the future will look like.I used to have a fairly active social life – meeting friends at their houses or the pub, seeing family and friends in different parts of the country, going to dancing lessons and a weekly fitness class. All of these have been cancelled. My workplace will be quite different when we return, and it may still involve some working from home. I feel more grateful. People seem to be noticing human qualities more, and currently there appears to be a move away from materialism and consumerism. This is very positive. At my work and where I live, people seem to take more time to talk to one another and to find out how they are. My colleagues and workplace are very supportive, well-being is a high and lived priority, which is very important. I now speak to my neighbours more and friends in other countries- due to the connection of the pandemic. Life has a slower pace. I feel a bit more at peace.Challenges come in wanting to talk to friends online, but friends having different needs. A challenge also comes from waking up each day and remembering that life is different as well as from others not following the lockdown rules and the loss of life. I'm very curious, so I try to see this as a new situation, a change in lifestyle and the potential for a better society. The impact on the environment is hugely positive, and having time to reflect is a treasured gift.I have started golf and tennis lessons. I've reconnected with friends and lost two stone through running. I've learnt to bake bread and I've started yoga and pilates. I feel strong and amazing.I've spent positive quality time with my sons and I've realised how important family is. But it is challenging being confined as I love movement and travel and seeing friends. It's the hardest job on earth being a single parent with zero support.My 86-year-old mum lives 320 miles away and is partially deaf so phone calls have become frustrating for both of us. We used to text and message regularly but knowing that she wouldn’t be seeing anyone as she normally would, we started to video call her each day via Facebook messenger. We play a game for an hour each day and she likes to see our dogs and play around with the filter effects on the the end of the call. I speak to my mum every day rather than every few weeks and I order her groceries online. I now feel more helpful to her than I’ve ever been.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: private schools plea ministers allow year groups return classroom
story: Private school chiefs are pleading with ministers to allow more of their pupils to return next month, saying that their “hands are tied” without permission from the Government.Fee-paying institutions have been lobbying the Department of Education (DfE) to give them some flexibility about which year groups they are allowed to welcome back from June 1. But they say that their pleas have fallen on deaf ears, leaving them unable to secure the insurance cover they need to reopen.The Prime Minister said that schools should prepare to open for pupils in Reception, Year One and Year Six to return to school from June 1, with the “ambition” that all primary school children could be back in the classroom by the end of the month.Neil Roskilly, chief executive of the Independent School Association, said that two things are stopping private schools from going their own way.“The first is that ministers are saying they expect private schools to follow the pattern of state schools, he said. And the second is insurance companies which are refusing to cover schools’ legal liability if they go against the Government’s recommendation.”Headteachers’ “hands are tied” without liability cover from their insurers, he explained. “The insurance companies say ‘we won’t cover you, open at your own risk’. It’s a real dampener. Some schools are looking at whether parents can sign a disclaimer – but you can’t sign away negligence.If I was a parent and I was being asked to sign a disclaimer to indemnify the school 100 per cent against a claim, I would think twice. It is not an ideal solution.Mr Roskilly said that in some parts of the country, local council chiefs who oppose a June 1 return have written to private as well as state schools to warn them against opening.“The message that comes back at the moment from ministers is that they don’t want to consider variation,” he said. “I think there is a lot of sympathy, they do understand this issue.But what they don’t want to be doing is saying that independent schools can do one thing, and state schools can do another. Academies, I am sure, would love to have flexibility as well.“I am hoping that something will change with that between now and June. The bottom line is that it would be safe for schools to apply a level of variation.”Christopher King, chief executive of the Independent Prep School Association, also said that the Government’s lack of flexibility is proving difficult for his 670 members.Prep schools already tend to have smaller class sizes, he explained, adding that many are in rural areas with “significant amounts” of outdoor that can be used for social distancing. “Our schools would welcome the prospect of bringing more groups back,” he said. “For a good number of our members, the key transition is at Year Eight rather than Year Six so we would prefer to have them back in.  But we were told that the Government has decided that, for the simplicity of messaging, to keep to Year Six.”    Mr King said it is a source of “considerably frustration” for private school heads that they are not able to act independently.  A governor at one of the country’s leading private schools told The : “It feels to me that officials are petrified of independent schools successfully reopening ahead of the state sector because it shows the weakness of the Government not being able to stand up to the unions.”He added that private schools should be allowed to take a common sense approach to reopening, adding: More and more people realise life needs to continue. We just want to crack on with it.  A DfE spokesperson said: “Plans for a cautious, phased return of some year groups from 1 June, at the earliest, are based on the best scientific and medical advice. The welfare of children and staff has been at the heart of all decision making.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: sadiq khan showboating mediocrity london deserves better
story: Amid the gloom, some glad tidings. Coronavirus is disappearing from the capital. Once the worst-hit region in the UK, London is surging ahead in its recovery. Seventeen per cent of Londoners are now believed to be immune. This is inspirational, not just for regions lagging behind but in providing a compelling case for easing the city’s lockdown. The Government’s ill-timed and indiscriminate quarantine measures have made it utterly crucial to kickstart domestic growth. Yet the UK’s economic powerhouse remains under lockdown.Good thing that we London-dwellers have been blessed with a globally-minded Mayor, then? Sadly, Sadiq “London is open” Khan is missing in action. Instead of fighting to get the city moving, he has only hampered its recovery by hiking congestion charges. His decision to slash underground journeys meant cramming commuters into packed tubes. Under his watch, Transport for London has become a hotbed of waste, protectionism and mismanagement.Though progress remains stubbornly slow, developments suggest the Government is finally rethinking both its one-size-fits-all approach to lockdown, and its indulgent attitude towards Khan’s leadership. A new taskforce, jointly chaired by Khan and Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick, will look to “restart” London’s economy. The latter appointment bodes well. Jenrick has had a good “coronavirus war” getting rough sleepers off the streets, restarting construction projects and spearheading deregulation measures. He epitomises the anti-Sadiq tendency making sensible decisions without fanfare.With Mayoral elections looming, however, the Conservatives must also contend with the forces of revisionism. Already, Khan is attributing TfL’s £1.6 billion government bailout to the shock of Covid-19, and it is vital that the Tories do not allow this narrative to gain traction. Though no one could expect TfL to weather the shock of a 90 per cent drop in incomes under lockdown, City Hall’s finances were in a parlous state long before the pandemic.While TfL operated at a loss, Khan indulged in costly gesture politics banning “junk” food and and political adverts (he made an exception for the People’s Vote campaign), leaving a £13 million financial hole. He doubled his own PR budget and ramped up City Hall staffing spending. To court favour with the electorate and vested interest groups, he scattered giveaways like confetti, leaving many travelling for free when they could easily afford it. Though his grandstanding played to the vanities of “liberal” Londoners, it was built on arrogant foundations the expectation of infinite subsidy and an assumption that the city belonged to Labour forever.This pandemic – and the patchy response across the four regions – has exposed the limits of Britain’s devolved settlement. Though this taskforce looks unlikely to give City Hall the radical shake-up it deserves, it is heartening to see Westminster finally defend its corner. London is too important to be in the hands of a showboating mediocrity.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: site sore eyes florences duomo reopens high tech social distancing
story: Like generations of pilgrims before them they stared in wonder up at the interior of Brunelleschi’s 295ft high Duomo, enraptured by all its renaissance glory.But there was something distinctive that marked out these visitors to Florence’s Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore from the thousands of cultural tourists and devout worshippers who have come before.Around their necks hung a special gadget designed to emit an alarm each time they strayed too close to another visitor.Welcome to sightseeing in the age of Covid-19.Not that anyone was complaining. For those who had queued up on Friday, on the first day of its reopening since Italy’s strict lockdown began, it was enough simply to be able to enter the doors of the great cathedral and enjoy its ornate interiors once again.“Finalmente!” shouted one woman in delight as the doors were swung open by masked security staff. “At last!”The special devices, which are anonymous and do not track any data and are issued free on entry to each visitor, flash, vibrate and beep when people come within two metres of each other (see picture below). Timothy Verdon, director of the Duomo Museum, said the cathedral is the first in the world to employ such a device in a museum setting, adding that visitor numbers will be reduced in line with Italy's continuing social distancing measures, with online booking and masks now obligatory.At the entrance, guards used thermal scanners to take the temperature of visitors, before each one was given one of the devices. These will later be disinfected before being used again.While this may appear an antiseptic way of enjoying one of the world’s greatest churches it will come as a welcome relief to hundreds of Italians and foreign visitors, deprived until now of a glimpse of the ine since churches and cultural institutions shut in March.It's beautiful and touching to see the Duomo open again, especially since it's not often that you see it so empty, said Marco, a local resident. It's even better that way.Gabriele, another Florentine, pointed out that visits to the cathedral and its associated sights - which include the famous octagonal Baptistery and Giotto's free-standing 85 metre tall Campanile - were free until the end of the month.It's been so many years since I've gone inside the Duomo. It's a perfect occasion to take advantage of with fewer tourists and people, he said. It's a great feeling.Within 24 hours of the announcement that the Duomo was to re-open, more than 10,000 people reserved tickets.The Duomo’s administrators said they were surprised by the overwhelming enthusiasm of those who wanted to visit the building, begun in 1296 in the Gothic style and not completed until 1436, with the building of Filippo Brunelleschi’s Dome.  Lorenzo Luchetti, director general of Opera di Santa Maria del Fiore, which administers the cathedral, said the reopening marked a symbolic moment for Italy following the ordeal of the pandemic, which has killed more than 32,600 people on the peninsula.We decided to reopen free of charge for everyone to give a message of hope, of revival, of a return to normal life, he said.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: wind farms paid record 93m switch turbines
story: Wind farms in Britain were paid a record £.9.3m to switch off their turbines on Friday, The Sunday  can disclose.More than 80 plants across England and Scotland were handed the so-called 'constraint payments', when supply outstrips demand, by the National Grid, as thousands of buildings lying empty following the coronavirus lockdown contributed to a nosee in demand for energy.In what has been declared a national embarrassment and a power management disgrace by campaigners, consumers will ultimately foot the bill of £6.9m to 66 Scottish plants and £1.9m to 14 offshore plants in England.This is almost double the previous single day record payout to wind farm operators, which was £4.8m on Oct 8, 2018, when turbines were switched off because it became too windy.It is believed the low demand for electricity on May 22 was due to windy and sunny weather this week, with solar panels likely to have produced a lot of energy, combined with the lack of demand for power given the Covid-19 lockdown which has seen many businesses close.So worrying was the development that the National Grid issued an alert to stop it happening for a second day running.Dr John Constable, director of Renewable Energy Foundation, a UK charity that monitors energy use, said: “Overdeployment of renewables in the UK, particularly uncontrollable wind and solar, has resulted in a very fragile electricity system, which is inflexible and unable to deal with accidents and unexpected circumstances at a reasonable cost to consumers.Grid balancing expenditure so far this year is already horrific and by the end of the summer it will be terrifying.This is a national embarrassment, and a disgrace to the management of the electricity sector who have complacently allowed this crisis to develop over the last decade.”The charity previously revealed that the operators of 86 wind farms in Britain were handed a record of more than £136m in constraint payments last year.Investing in new grid infrastructure is vital so that renewable generators can continue to provide consumers with the massive quantities of cheap electricity we need to achieve net zero emissions.“Constraint payments are the cheapest way for National Grid to run the electricity network within its current limits.All types of generation, including fossil fuels, receive them, but unlike older technologies, wind farms can turn off or on within a matter of seconds, and so wind is often called on by National Grid to vary its output. So it’s actually the best way to keep bills as low as possible.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: hertz car hire bankruptcy coronavirus stock price
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘No business is built for zero revenue,’ says firm’s former chief executive.&nbsp‘There’s only so long that companies’ reserves will carry them’The 102-year-old car rental company Hertz has filed for bankruptcy after the coronavirus pandemic caused business to nosee.At the end of March, the firm was $18.7 billion (£15.3 billion) in debt with only $1 billion (£820 million) of available cash.Hertz, which has over 400 outlets across the UK and Ireland, recently cut 12,000 staff from its global workforce and put another 4,000 on furlough. Chief executive Kathryn Marinello resigned last week following reports of possible bankruptcy.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe company lost all revenue from mid-March when the global travel industry came to a shuddering halt. Much of the firm’s income is sourced from car rentals at airports but it started missing debt payments in April.Ms Marinello said at the company’s first-quarter earnings conference on 12 May: “No business is built for zero revenue. There’s only so long that companies’ reserves will carry them.”Why businesses should think about going flight-freeBusinesses are a bit more optimistic, but we're heading for recessionHow the Government is helping UK businesses in the Covid-19 crisisNew insolvency law to stop businesses going bust during pandemicIn the company’s first-quarter report earlier this month with securities regulators, Hertz warned it may not be able to repay or refinance debt and may not have enough cash to continue operations.The report said: “Management has concluded there is substantial doubt regarding the company’s ability to continue as a going concern within one year from the issuance date of this quarterly report.”Hertz said in a statement on Friday: “The impact of Covid-19 on travel demand was sudden and dramatic, causing an abrupt decline in the company’s revenue and future bookings.“Hertz took immediate actions to prioritise the health and safety of employees and customers, eliminate all non-essential spending and preserve liquidity.“However, uncertainty remains as to when revenue will return and when the used-car market will fully re-open for sales, which necessitated today’s action. The financial reorganisation will provide Hertz a path toward a more robust financial structure that best positions the company for the future as it navigates what could be a prolonged travel and overall global economic recovery.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Premium.Retailer says social distancing wardens will patrol stores to ensure measures are workingIkea is set to reopen 19 stores across England and Northern Ireland from 1 June with a new series of safety measures to ensure social distancing, the retailer has announced.The homeware chain has said social distancing wardens will patrol each store to make sure rules are being followed and the number of customers will be limited to reduce the risk of spreading coronavirus.However, stores in Scotland, Wales and Ireland will remain closed, in line with government guidance.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIkea voluntarily closed its stores in March before the UK government's lockdown was announced due to the Covid-19 outbreak.To ensure stores do not become too busy, the safety remains our top priority, and that’s why we’ve put in place extensive measures to ensure the safety and comfort of customers and co-workers.”The 19 stores reopening are Croydon, Greenwich, Lakeside, Wembley, Tottenham, Norwich collection point, Birmingham, Nottingham, Belfast, Manchester, Warrington, Gateshead, Leeds, Sheffield, Milton Keynes, Reading, Southampton, Bristol and Exeter.Extra hand sanitiser facilities will be introduced and more frequent deep cleaning of bags, trolleys, bathrooms, equipment and touchscreens will take place, the retailer said.Cash will also not
