title: dominic cummings lockdown boris
story: DEFIANT Dominic Cummings today claimed he didnt break government lockdown rules by travelling to see his family in the north east. Boris Johnsons chief adviser travelled more than  miles from his London home to stay with his parents in Durham so his sister could look after his child while he had coronavirus symptoms.After being backed by No this morning, Mr Cummings told reporters outside his home in London: I behaved reasonbly and legally.When asked by reportershis trip to Durham during lockdown looked good,  he added: “Who cares about good looks  It’s a question of doing the right thing. It’s not about what you guys think.”Boris Johnson has faced heated calls to sack Mr Cummings today.But an official statement from Downing Street gave Nos full backing and said he didnt break government guidance because he and his we, journalist Mary Wakefield, stayed in a dferent building.A No spokesperson also challenged reports the aide and his family had been spoken to by police.A statement said: Owing to his we being infected with suspected coronavirus and the high likelihood that he would himself become unwell, it was essential for Dominic Cummings to ensure his young child could be properly cared for.His sister and nieces had volunteered to help so he went to a house near to but separate from his extended family in case their help was needed.His sister shopped for the family and left everything outside.At no stage was he or his family spoken to by the police about this matter, as is being reported.His actions were in line with coronavirus guidelines.Mr Cummings reportedly travelled to Durham so his parents could help with child care while he and his we had Covid- symptoms.He contracted coronavirus at the end of March. At the time Downing Street claimed he was holed up in his London home.A week later, on April , a neighbour spotted Mr Cummings in the garden with his son running around to Abba’s Dancing Queen.They said: “I got the shock of my le, as I looked over to the gates and saw him.“There was a child, presumably his little boy, running around in front. I recognised Dominic Cummings, he’s a very distinctive figure.”The revelation comes despite No telling Brits they must stay at home and not see family to slow the spread of Covid.The move allegedly went against advice, which became law on March , which stated: “You should not be visiting family members who do not live in your home.”Only in exceptional circumstances were people allowed to attend relatives addresses for example, to drop off food or medicine to their door.Durham Constabulary said they had spoken to Mr Cummings’ parents - which has been denied by No - about his visit.A spokesman for the force said: “On Tuesday, March , our officers were made aware of reports that an inidual had travelled from London to Durham and was present at an address in the city.“Officers made contact with the owners of that address who confirmed that the inidual in question was present and was self-isolating in part of the house.“In line with national policing guidance, officers explained to the family the guidelines around self-isolation and reiterated the appropriate advice around essential travel”.The news comes as the coronavirus death toll in the UK hit , today after  more deaths.Acting Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey today called for Mr Cummings to explain himself - or resign.He said: If Dominic Cummings has broken the lockdown guidelines, he will have to resign. Its as simple as that.And in an interview with Sky News today, he said: It looks quite outrageous that the PMs closest adviser has done this.The Labour Party has demanded a very swt explanation from Downing Street over reports that Mr Cummings broke the Governments lockdown rules.A Labour spokesman said: If accurate, the Prime Ministers chief adviser appears to have breached the lockdown rules.The Governments guidance was very clear: stay at home and no non-essential travel.The British people do not expect there to be one rule for them and another rule for Dominic Cummings.Number  needs to provide a very swt explanation for his actions.Acting Durham Police, Crime and Victims’ Commissioner, Steve White, called Mr Cummings decision most unwise.But senior Tory officials have come out in support of Mr Cummings today.Minister Michael Gove has taken to Twitter in suppoer od Mr Cummings, writing: Caring for your we and child is not a crime.Chancellor Rishi Sunak also wrote on social media: Taking care of your we and young child is justiable and reasonable, trying to score political points over it isn’t.Journalist Mary Wakefield revealed that No chief Mr Cummings, , spent  days bedridden after collapsing and having spasms.In the article, Wakfield said her husband was nursed by their young son - despite new claims the family had travelled to Durham for child care.She said: My husband did rush home to look after me.He’s an extremely kind man, whatever people assume to the contrary.But  hours later, he said, ‘I feel weird’ and collapsed.I felt breathless, sometimes achy, but Dom couldn’t get out of bed.Day in, day out for ten days he lay doggo with a high fever and spasms that made the muscles lump and twitch in his legs. He could breathe, but only in a limited, shallow way.The little oxygen reader we’d bought on Amazon indicated that he should be in hospital, but his lips weren’t blue and he could talk in full sentences, she wrote.She also appears to have suggested the family remained at their London home for the duration of the illness, writing: After the uncertainty of the bug itself, we emerged from quarantine into the almost comical uncertainty of London lockdown.Dominic Raab posted: It’s reasonable and fair to ask for an explanation on this.And it has been provided: two parents with coronavirus, were anxiously taking care of their young child.Those now seeking to politicise it should take a long hard look in the mirror.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.

title: kids scarred unions stopping school return
story: THE lockdown is scarring children for le, scientists warned yesterday.Kids are undergoing a “shock” that will last into adulthood.And unless they get back into the classroom soon they will have LESS chance to socialise with pals and LESS hope of getting opportunities in future.Yet hardline unions are fighting plans for a phasedfor primary schools from June  — despite children being LESS likely to catch the coronavirus.On top of that, safeguards would include classes being halved in size to just  pupils.Schools would be carefully cleaned and children placed in protective “bubbles” preventing them mixing with kids or staff in other groups.Breaks and lunches would be staggered and classes held outside wherever possible.If all went well, every primary pupil couldby June  to squeeze in a full month before the summer holidays.A report published yesterday by the Government’s Sage scientic advisory group detailed the cost the shutdown was already having.It warned: “A cohort of children has experienced a shock to their education which will persist and affect their educational and work outcomes for the rest of their lives. Similarly, the current lockdown may lead to an increase in adverse childhood experiences — for example, domestic violence, poor parental mental health, child neglect or abuse.”These are all “associated with worse long-term health outcomes, and will likely exacerbate existing societal inequalities”. And they added the impact on “educational attainment, health outcomes” and social inequality is “critical”.But the documents also said the risk to children of reopening schools was “very low”.One study they considered found that children are  per cent less likely to catch the virus.The scientists stressed: “Evidence remains inconclusive on both the susceptibility and infectivity of children, but the balance of evidence suggests that both may be lower than in adults.”Chief Scientic Adviser Sir Patrick Vallance told yesterday’s Downing Street press conference: “The risks to children of this disease are much lower. We know that — they are at very low risk.“Not zero risk — and there have been some serious cases in children of course — but very few compared to adults and older age groups.”Ministers want schools to reopen for reception, Year s and Year  on June , with the rest of primary pupils and Year s and Year s ing gradually afterwards.Sage believes an “effective test, trace and isolate system” to battle Covid- should be in place before schools reopen. PM Boris Johnson has pledged to get one up and running by the time kidsin little more than a week.A source close to the deliberations said heading back to class should be no riskier for kids than venturing outside.They added: “The risk is very low. It’s not zero, but that remains true for every activity outside the house where you might come into contact with people.”They said teachers would be at no higher risk than millions of other key workers.Sage modelled a string of plans to reopen schools, from ordering all kids back to class, to limiting it to certain year groups.The Government’s plan to limit class sizes to  and only have a phasedof some year groups first — starting with among the youngest — was not modelled. But the documents suggest it is one of the most cautious approaches.Last night Prof Matthew Snape, of Oxford University, said: “Underlying all this needs to be the recognition that Covid- in children is, fortunately, rare. The information we have suggests this would remain the case for all scenarios of school reopening.”However teaching union the National Education Union, which had been furiously demanding the Sage advice be published, still vowed to fight the back-to-school plan.Joint general secretary Dr Mary Bousted said: “It remains the case that the National Education Union does not yet think it safe for the wider opening of schools.“In addition to track and trace and the case numbers, we need to see regular testing and PPE for those who need it.” She even accused the Government of adopting a “cavalier attitude towards the nation’s children”.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson, pictured far left, hit back: “The papers published by Sage today show that the phased, cautiousof a limited number of pupils to classrooms has been a carefully considered decision based on the best scientic and medical advice.“My department continues to engage with the school, college and nursery sectors and I am enormously grateful for all the planning and preparation they are doing, alongside local authorities and academy trusts.“The welfare of children remains at the very heart of everything we are doing because being able to be back in school will benefit not just their education but also their wellbeing.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: left scientific evidence schools reopening disgrace
story: THE confusion and fear sown among ­parents by militant union leaders and Labour MPs backing a bogus scientic group with a political grudge is a national ­disgrace with disastrous consequences.Official advice from Sage shows some schools can reopen ­cautiously but safely on June .Kids are  per cent less likely to catch Covid-, “likely to play a smaller role in transmitting the virus” and the “balance of risk is strongly toto school”.And teachers are in no more danger than millions of other key workers. Parents naturally worry their children are more vulnerable to any disease. It’s not so with coronavirus. Mums and dads should take confidence from that.And yet, defying the best impartial evidence available, the Left has terried Britain into a revolt. No, ing to school cannot be  per cent safe. What is, short of staying home forever hoping for a vaccine Meanwhile the lockdown damage to kids’ education, mental health and le chances is almost unimaginable.Corbynite NEU chief Mary Bousted cynically sneers: “It’s just descending into chaos now” before talking up the opposing claims of the so-called “Independent Sage Committee” and bemoaning the “confusion” for parents.Who caused this chaos and confusion  People like her. title: tony hadley quiz win cash prize
story: Muhammad Shalehan missed out on £, when radio bosses said he had mispronounced the singer’s name.But when Tony, , ­intervened they backtracked and gave Muhammad his money.In a video the singer of  No single True reckoned: “You might have had a slight accent but, as far as I’m concerned, you said my name correctly. You should be entitled to the prize.”Muhammad declared: “I am so happy. I couldn’t have done it without the help of Mr Tony Hadley.”The father of three had correctly guessed  mystery celeb voices on Singapore’s Gold  radio station. But the presenter said he had got one name wrong.Two weeks later another caller listed the same  names, including Tony’s, and was declared the ­winner. Muhammad questioned the decision saying that the presenter must have misheard his accent.The radio station refused to cough up and offered half the prize as compo. Angry Muhammad, , found Tony’s manager online and emailed him.The singer replied with a video, endorsing the pronunciation of his name.Gold  then backed down and said: “Since Tony Hadley has said that Mr Shalehan said his name correctly, who are we to disagree ”Muhammad said: “My message to Mr Tony Hadley is a big, big, big thank you. His video was a great, great game-changer.”In the Celebrity Name Drop contestants had to guess each of the celebs who said a word in the slogan “Gold --, the station that sounds good, and makes you feel good”.Each time a listener had a go they were told how many they got right, but not which ones.Over the weeks punters could gradually work out which names were correct.Railway worker Muhammad called hundreds of times and got on air twice. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: weather forecast bank holiday scorcher
story: BOOKIES are predicting the May Spring Bank holiday will be the hottest on record for  years with the mercury hitting C. The Met Office predicts temperatures will reach C but bookies are offering odds of just   on the UK reaching temperatures of C in coming week.The sunny weather is set to test the nations resolve in maintaining coronavirus social distancing in parks and open spaces.Police chiefs have said that people were becoming blasé about social distancing as the health secretary pleaded with the public to be sensible over the warm weekend.Speaking at the Downing Street press conference, Matt Hancock said: Lets not go back to square one.We can all play our part in the national effort.While itll be fairly breezy with patches of rain in the north of the country tomorrow there will be sunny spells everywhere.Monday is likely to be the hottest day and temperatures are likely to peak to a balmy C in some areas.The Met office says the movement of the jet stream is playing a big part in the weekends weather.As it moves north, high pressure will build, bringing sunny weather for many on tomorrow and Monday.On Twitter the Met office has been warning people should stay at home to save lives.They said: The movement of the JetStream will play a big part in the weekend weather.As it moves north, high pressure will build, bringing sunny weather for many on Sunday and Monday.

title: piers morgan gmb ban cabinet ministers dominic cummings
story: PIERS Morgan has banned cabinet ministers who backed Dominic Cummings from appearing on Good Morning Britain after more allegations about the governments chief adviser.The TV host announced the ban as pressure on Cummings mounted for him to step down after allegations he visited his parents in Durham twice during lockdown.Prime Minister Johnson is facing calls to axe chief adviser Dominic Cummings today after he travelled more than  miles with coronavirus symptoms from London to his parents home in Durham.It is now claimed the PMs top aide was seen with his we in Houghall Woods two weeks after he first visited there while suffering from Covid- symptoms, the Sunday Mirror reports.Piers took to his Twitter page to write: In light of today’s developments, I am regretfully forced to ban all cabinet ministers from appearing on @GMB until further notice.Only exceptions will be those who didn’t publicly support Cummings breaching a lockdown that the Govt forced on the rest of us ‘to save lives’.In another message he said: Remember their names before listing cabinet ministers andthey had backed the government official.Officials from Downing Street say Mr Cummings didnt break Government guidance on lockdown because he and his we, journalist Mary Wakefield, stayed in a dferent building.Earlier in the day Piers had  vowed to break lockdown rulesCummings wasnt sacked.He tweeted: If Boris doesn’t fire Cummings today, then I will deem the lockdown over  drive down to see my parentsfor the first time in  weeks.I’m not having one rule for these clowns  another for the rest of us.Senior Tory minister Michael Gove added fuel to the fire by commenting: Caring for your we and child is not a crime.But Piers hit back: Oh please. Cummings brazenly broke the rules YOUR Govt - advised by HIM - enforced on everyone .The TV star also Tweeted Health Secretary Matt Hancock directly, asking: Do you stand by Dominic Cummings And in another message, Piers posted: Cummings didnt have a single person in London who could drop food outside his door Either he is the most friendless human being in the world, or hes a liar.Mr Cummings reportedly travelled to Durham so his parents could help with child care while the aide and his we, journalist Mary Wakefield, had Covid- symptoms.He contracted coronavirus at the end of March.At the time Downing Street claimed he was holed up in his London home.Mr Cummings we gave a detailed account of the familys coronavirus ordeal in her Spectator column - but failed to mention that they had allegedly broken lockdown.Mrs Wakefield revealed that No chief Mr Cummings, , spent  days bedridden after collapsing and having spasms.She also appears to have suggested the family remained at their London home for the duration of the illness, writing: After the uncertainty of the bug itself, we emerged from quarantine into the almost comical uncertainty of London lockdown.Durham Constabulary confirmed they had visited the home of Mr Cummings’ parents - Robert and Morag - and given the family a ticking off.A spokesman for the force said: “On Tuesday, March , our officers were made aware of reports that an inidual had travelled from London to Durham and was present at an address in the city.“Officers made contact with the owners of that address who confirmed that the inidual in question was present and was self-isolating in part of the house.“In line with national policing guidance, officers explained to the family the guidelines around self-isolation and reiterated the appropriate advice around essential travel”.A No spokesperson said today: Owing to his we being infected with suspected coronavirus and the high likelihood that he would himself become unwell, it was essential for Dominic Cummings to ensure his young child could be properly cared for.His sister and nieces had volunteered to help so he went to a house near to but separate from his extended family in case their help was needed. His sister shopped for the family and left everything outside.At no stage was he or his family spoken to by the police about this matter, as is being reported.His actions were in line with coronavirus guidelines.Mr Cummings believes he behaved reasonably and legally.It comes weeks after Professor Lockdown resigned his Government post after breaching lockdown rules at least twice.Prof Neil Ferguson, , allowed his married lover to visit him at home during the lockdown while lecturing the public on the need for strict social distancing to halt the spread of Covid-.

title: couple raffle 290000 cottage they spent two years renovating
story: The stunning property was originally built in the s, and is now worth £,.Katherine Jablonowska and Ryan Mclean bought the property in , and worked -hour days to transform it into a luxurious home.It is located on the Llŷn Penninsula in North Wales, on the outskirts of Snowdonia National Park.The pair are now looking to sell the two-bed cottage through a raffle which costs just a fiver to enter.Pictures of the property show a wood burning stove, a stylish lounge and a large outside space with incredible views.Ms Jablonowska, , and Mr Mclean, , are hoping that , people will enter the competition, with the winner being drawn on September .The couple are also asking for entrants to donate an extra £ to The Children’s Society charity, and say they will match every donationthey reach their ticket sales target.Ms Jablonowska said: “The idea was in the back of our minds for a few years. We had come across raffles in the news every now and then.“We thought: ‘That’s a good idea’. So we spent some time researching it – and thought it was a fantastic way to sell a house.”“It gives someone the chance to get on the property ladder. It’s a little piece of heaven.”Mr Mclean said: “It’s been quite the journey. It took approximately  months.“It was long, hard days – from am to pm. It turned out to be exactly what we needed.“But we had some idea of what we were doing. title: boy weeps joy first mcdonalds meal lockdown
story: Mum Wati filmed herself showing Adam Bin Mohammad Irwan, who has autism, a table laden with food from the chain after weeks stuck at home.The clip opens with Atwi sat in her car and saying to the camera: Hello guys. Im [getting] McDonalds. Its a surprise!She buys the food and conceals it in plastic bags, though jokes: I think the smell will give it away.She then leads Adam through the home and into the dining room.Adam initially thinks his mum is playing a prank, so begins to run around the table and shriek before spotting the food.He then begins to cry before running back and giving his mum a hug.I thought you wanted to scare me, he says.His mum responded: I didnt want to scare you! I wanted to surprised you. Look, what is it McDonalds, he says.Adam is then seen eating from a box of chicken nuggets.Wati later shared the video to Facebook, where it has been viewed over , times.Reacting to the clip, one user wrote: This boys genuine reaction is enough to move anyones heart.She said that McNuggets with fries and ice cream was Adams favourite meal, adding that his overreaction was caused by his sensory sensitivity and mild autism.Lockdown was first imposted in Singapore on April , and all McDonalds outlets have been closed since April .

title: what time coronavirus press briefing today saturday may 23
story: THE UK Government will address the country todayas part of the daily coronavirus briefings slightly before pm, to be led by Transport Secretary Grant Shapps.The daily press conferences aim to inform the public on any crucial decisions being taken by the Government to combat Covid-.The briefing will be held from Downing Street slightly earlier today and is scheduled to kick off at .pm.A Government minister will address the country via a live broadcast.It has been reported that Transport Secretary Grant Shapps will be speaking today.The press conference briefings are broadcast live by the BBC at pm weekdays and pm weekends.You can also watch the live broadcast on the Governments official YouTube page.We can keep you up to date on what is being said at the press conference by following our coronavirus live blog, for live updates on the briefing.Home Secretary Priti Patel addressed the nation at the coronavirus press conference.She was joined by Paul Lincoln, head of the UKs Border Force, and Sir Patrick Vallance, chief scientic adviser to the UK government.Priti Patel started the address by revealing the Government is enforcing a new quarantine measure to prevent a second wave of Covid-.This new measure means all visitors entering the UK will have to self-isolate for  days starting from June .Patel announced spot checks will take place, with arrivals being asked professionals will be amongst those not required to self-isolate for  days and that in extreme circumstances entry to the UK maybe refused to certain people who dont comply with quarantine measures.Priti Patel then continued to say: “The answer as to why were bringing in these measures now is simple: It is to protect that hard-won progress and prevent a devastating resurgence in a second wave of the virus.”The Home Secretary said the Government will work hard to support the international travel and tourism industry recover from the effects of this pandemic and reopen the title: labour leader keir starmer remainers brexit over
story: And he admitted his partys previous attitudes towards the split with the EU - which he partly oversaw as shadow Brexit secretary - had been damaging.In an interview with the , Sir Keir said Labour will now focus on what sort of a deal we have with the EU and what sort of deals we have with the rest of the world.He also said he wants the party to be proudly patriotic, and will not snub state occasions, like predecessor Jeremy Corbyn did.During the interview Sir Keir said: Weve left the EU, and therefore the Leave Remain argument is over and the only argument now is what sort of a deal we have with the EU and what sort of deals we have with the rest of the world.Its very important for the Labour party to be clear that whatever position we and others may have taken in the last three-and-a-half, four years, that ide between Leave and Remain is now over.Asked whether he will try to take the UK back into the bloche wins the next general election, he said: I dont think theres a case for rejoining the EU and Im certainly not making that case.Sir Keir hopes to lead Labour away from the political wilderness after its worst election showing since .And he said the party is proud of its roots.Im proud that were patriotic, he said.I dont think we should be shy about it.I think it is something we should be very proud of.Jeremy Corbyn refused to attend a state banquet given in honour of President Donald Trump in April .After snubbing the Queens invite and ripping up his invitation, he was branded unfit to be PM.But Sir Keir said he wouldnt refuse any ceremonial occasion.Ive never shied away from these events, he said.Ive attended them when I was director of public prosecutions.No doubt Ill attend them as leader of the Labour party. Sir Keir has also called for schools to reopen as soon as possible - and says his son and daughter have attended class throughout the coronavirus pandemic.This week, the UK sparked a fresh Brexit showdown with Brussels after defying demands for new border posts in Northern Ireland.Government documents published on Wednesday confirmed there will need to be checks on some goods entering Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK from January next year once the Brexit transition period has ended.

title: we must get back to work or well leave our children a legacy of debt
story: IF the financial effect of coronavirus was a tsunami, this was the week that we began to realise that we ain’t seen nothing yet.In fact, we are currently still standing on the beach, watching the sea recede, waiting for that giant wave to hit us.In mid-April, Chancellor Rishi Sunak was still saying that the UK would bounce back from the economic impact of this pandemic.But last week he predicted we are facing a recession the likes of which we have never seen.But cocooned as we are in the relatively cushioned existence of lockdown, it’s hard to imagine what that will actually mean for our everyday lives when we emerge from it.Many people’s salaries are more or less intact, thanks to the Government’s furlough scheme. The shock will come when that scheme ends, bringing a new wave of unemployment — predicted by some to be in double digits by the end of the year.As a result, the tax that we rely on to pay for essential public ­services such as the NHS, police, teachers and even MPs dwindles catastrophically.This will put a colossal strain on government funds. One result will be a reduction in finance for public services — and never-ending cuts.The gloomiest assessment of our future is that we don’t need to worry about whether restaurants will reopen, or fear airlines going bust, because we won’t be able to afford to eat out or holiday anywhere.We will be working hard to stand still, which is a rotten position to be in.At the moment, the Government is paying the wages of ten million ­people and giving them loans to survive. That was and is the right thing to do.But the cost to the public — ­estimated to be £BILLION this year — will be vast. And it’s growing all the time.Whichever way you look at it, with lockdown we have swallowed a very poisonous pill. In fact, it may go down in history as the greatest act of self-harm any civilisation has ever inflicted upon itself.Yes, it has saved some people, although not enough of the elderly living in care homes.But we have created a financial burden on the country that will last a generation. The economy is in freefall. It contracted . per cent in March, which is the biggest decline on record. Forget a recession — some say we face a depression.Usually this means higher public borrowing, higher taxes and an end to triple-lock pensions.Whatever happens, let’s just say that Boris Johnson’s election pledge not to raise income tax, National Insurance contributions or VAT for five years is on thin ice.Butthe Government tries to cover this exceptional cost from the current economy we will crash — and we will all be worse off.Rather than start taxing everyone to the hilt, I can see a better solution — with interest rates at rock bottom levels, theGovernment should borrow the money instead, becausetaxes rise too quickly it will halt growth. And growth in the economy is the single most important step to recovery.So we need to borrow, and spread the debt over a long period of  to  years, like the old wartime bonds, to cover the short-term shortfall. If we borrow over a long enough period we could actually increase spending in the short term to incentivise growth.Andwe bounce back, we can pay off our debt more quickly.We just need to get out of lockdown to get this process started.Shops and businesses must open up and start trading again. And we have to get the schools open.People cannot worktheir kids are not in school or in high-quality childcare.If trains and buses are too crowded for people to get to work, we have to find other ways to travel, or work from homewe can.But, perhaps most importantly, we have to accept that this virus is here and it’s not going away.We have to protect the most vulnerable, and those at risk should remain in lockdown for their own safety.The rest of us must take responsibility for ourselves. We need to keep social distance, wear facemasks, wash our hands and stay at homewe have symptoms. We must not take risks.But the quicker people get back to work, the more the recession can be moderated — and we all have a part to play in that.AS proposals go, the one by the man who set out five sausages like fingers on a plate, with his grandmother’s ring on the fourth one, could have been more romantic.Although he also wrote, “Will you marry me ” in HP Sauce on some toast.Presumably this man understands his girlfriend well enough to know what she likes.And when she stopped laughing, I’m guessing she probably said yes.After all, it’s the thought that counts.THIS week, something wonderful happened.It was announced that Captain Tom Moore will be awarded a knighthood after raising a remarkable £million for NHS charities.Cpt Tom, who just turned  and has been promoted to honorary colonel, said on Good Morning Britain he is “thrilled that Her Majesty has chosen poor little me to be knighted”, adding: “It really is a great honour and something I never ever anticipated.“It never, ever entered my head that something like that could happen to me.”But this genuinely could not be more well-deserved.With all the misery we have had to endure over the past few months, this is a little ray of sunshine.Bravo again, Sir Tom.DID anyone  get the giggles at this picture, right, of the Russian nurse wearing only her undies beneath a transparent protective gown Hospital chiefs were not amused and ­punished the nurse for “non- compliance with the requirements for medical clothing”.ONE of the many revelations of lockdown is what a dferent place the House of Commons is without most MPs being there in person.There are far fewer places for people to hide without the armies of grown men and women braying and shouting over each other.As a result, a new type of order is prevailing.The Speaker, Sir Lindsay Hoyle, actually threatened to kick out Health Secretary Matt Hancock after he interrupted Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer at Prime Minister’s Questions.Hoyle treated Matt Hancock like a naughty schoolboy – which doesn’t feel right.But respect is earned and should be mutual.Perhaps one silver lining of lockdown will be a more respectful atmosphere in the Commons.I’VE been reflecting this week on what I’ve learned during the pandemic.Yes, I could share my theories here about human kindness and human idiocy, both of which have been on display in abundance over the past couple of months.Many of us have had time to think about what really matters and what doesn’t.We probably all have a mental list of things we most value from the “old” le, as well as silver linings and the benefits of the new way we have been living.But as we enter the ninth week of lockdownmy main conclusion, after a good deal of thought, is this: Women really do have superpowers.Most of the women I know are managing to . . . work from home, look after and home-school their children, cook and clean, shop for essentials, provide entertainment and keep up their family’s spirits, clap for carers and of course bake banana bread once a week.Now that’s what I call multi-tasking.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ghost hunters ran out haunted louisiana house free
story: The four-bedroom, three bathroom house in Youngsville, was built in the s, and is being given away for free after the the seller struggled to offload it amid creepy claims from previous occupants and visitors.McLain Investments co-owner, Sylvia McLain, posted the listing on Facebook a few months ago and was inundated with messages about it being haunted - after which the story made headlines around the world.Former resident Dawn Vallot DeClout claims the ghoul that occupies the house is her own great-grandmother, Adele, a ft in woman who lived to about  and can be heard stirring a pot in the kitchen.Others have alleged there are a number of spirits, some less welcoming than Adele, with weird noises being heard through the walls.Now, a ghost hunting duo from New Orleans, Cindy Parr and Greg Matlock Senior, have visited the home, claiming paranormal activity drained new batteries in their equipment and shut out a light, before they were confronted by a black figure.Shocking exclusive video footage also shows a door apparently slowing opening on its own after the team asked for a sign of a spirits presence.Recalling their spooky stay, Cindy told The Sun: On the second day, we actually went in and stayed the night, it killed five of our batteries, they feed off the energy.We asked for a signit wanted us to leave, and it shut down a light, we were like, okay, but we didnt leave yet.The bedroom door that was Ms Adeles, that opened up and then closed. It is definitely haunted, it was very creepy.As they continued to look around upstairs around am, Greg, who films footage for their YouTube channel, claims he was confronted by an evil spirit in another of the bedrooms towards the front of the house, stood beside a closet.He said: I turned into the room and saw this black mass standing there, it wasnt a shadow or anything like that, it was pretty wide.I dont think it was the older lady, I think it was something totally dferent, the figure was bigger and stood about ft.It started to turn and I just thought, Oh no and ran out, I was done, it was unbelievable, everything just slowed down.It wasnt just me seeing it, it was what I felt when it was there, you could feel the power, it was bad, not a good situation to be in at all.We got out and I was definitely exhausted, it draws energy from you, my chest was even hurting.Greg, who has been visiting haunted houses for more than  years, admitted the pair prayed and considered driving home after the encounter before ing.But he says things only got weirder, revealing: We could hear scratches on the walls, growls, it even started to smell like urine upstairs, thats not just your average ghost, thats something really bad.It was like watching Amityville Horror on TV, but we were living it. That house is definitely the worst house Ive ever been in.I want to see what happens when someone  lives in it, I dont think theyre going to be able to stay.Sylvia and her husband Bryan bought the  acres it sits on to build a new subision, and didnt want to demolish the home which remains in good shape.She revealed the house has now been snapped up and is being moved  to  miles away where a young woman will be the new, brave occupant.We do have someone that wants to move it, they havent started the work yet, its quite a project, theyre going to have to take it apart in three pieces, she said.Youve got to get permits and fix the power lines, its not an easy task and could cost up to ,.The man is in the construction business, hes going to move it himself and put it on his family land for his daughter.They wanted it because it was free, they couldnt care less about the history of it, they dont believe all the stories.Dawn Vallot DeClouts family owned the -acre plot the house was built on from  for more than  years, and she lived there for a year in .She previously said: We believe [Adele, her great-grandmother] is the ghost, but shes not menacing at all.She was always digging in the pots, like when you have something on the stove and someone goes and looks in the pot and stirs it around.She was well-known for that, and so when we lived there, we used to hear her all the time jangling the pots when we had something on the stove.You could hear somebody picking up the lid, but there was nobody in the kitchen.One person also comment on Sylvias Facebook post, revealing: I knew someone who rented it. Ive been in it.It is a lot less antique than youd expect. More like someone updated it in the s.Did have a lot of weird noises in the ceilings and walls though!Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Like us on Facebook at www.facebook TheSunUS and follow us from our main Twitter account at @TheSunUS.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rspca third more users online
story: The RSPCA reports almost a third more users for its Find A Pet section online – after more than a million people looked at it between March  and April .The charity rehomed more than  animals during this period, while  have been fostered – all while following guidelines put in place by the Canine  Feline Sector Group, formed by ious organisations to advise the Government on animals.An RSPCA spokesperson told Paws  Claws: “We are so pleased that we’ve been able to place more than  animals in loving homes and more than  of those have found their ‘for ever’ homes. But sticking to strict social- distancing guidelines means we will not be able to rehome all animals – for example, those who may need to meet any prospective owner a few times.”But others, including Nate the lurcher, five, are still waiting for their moment.Nate has been with the RSPCA Millbrook Animal Centre in Surrey for six months. He can be unsure of new places and people when he first meets them.Dogs like Nate, who need time to readjust, will need to meet prospective owners before being rehomed. Learn more aboutNate and other animals at rspca.org.uk findapet.Q SILKY my corn snake is not eating properly. In the past he’s always eaten what he’s given, usually mice. He’s also not touched any of his water. Can you suggest what I can do They have pretty exacting standards and for corn snakes there should be a fairly smooth gradient from about C at the warm end of their enclosure to low s at the cool end, dropping a few degrees at night.The second thing that springs to mind is stress. Too much handling or disturbance, or any environmental changes, will stress reptiles.Another possibility is that Silky is seeking a mate now summer is on the way — male corn snakes often act restless and lose appetite as they pick up on the longer hours of light.A check with an exotics-specialist vet is advisable. Snakes can hide their illness until it’s almost too late.Finley Bourke, , Edinburgh asks:Q MY six-year-old Staffordshire bull terrier Lucy loves to bark, moan, whine and make all sorts of noises. Should I be concerned  She seems otherwise happy and healthy.Darren Knighton,  Weston-super-Mare, Somerset asks:Q MY five-year-old boxer cross Poppy has started scratching herself a lot more than normal. She has even started to try to scratch herself when you smooth her back, and scratches in her sleep. She is neutered and wormed and I de-flea her regularly. I’ve also changed her food to hypoallergenic but she’s still itchy. Any ideas, please My guess is this could be a pollen allergy, though other factors such as dust mites, fungal spores and even household chemicals like detergents can play a role.The only definite way to find out is to run blood tests to check her anti-body levels to ious allergens. Then your vet can recommend treatment ranging from anti-itch medication to immunotherapy, which vaccinates her against her own allergies.It’s no fun to be itchy, so investing in finding out the cause and possible treatments will really help her.Henry Curtis, , Sheffield asksQ WHY do some dogs love snfing fox poo  Why does it smell terrible to us but apparently amazing to them  My Spaniel Peachy is guilty of this.We have two bundles – comprising blanket, cushion and mug – each worth £ up for grabs. See baileysblanket.For a chance to win, send an email marked “Personalised” to sundaypets@the-sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: japanese cult aum shinrikyo australian outback sarin experiments
story: The leader of Aum Supreme Truth believed the terrorist strike would trigger a nuclear war between superpowers and wanted a remote location to hide out so their preparations would go unnoticed.Two scouts, Kiyohide Hayakawa and Yoshihiro Inoue, were sent ahead in April  with the task of finding a remote spot in the Australian Outback.The pair eventually settled for Banjawam Station, , square kilometres of mulga and saltbush, about  hours drive north-east of Perth.The cult paid less than , for the land.Over the next  months the group used the area to conduct experiments with the sarin nerve agent, a chemical weapon developed in Nazi Germany.The experiments led to the attack on the Tokyo underground system in  which killed  people and poisoned another , commuters.A group of the sect’s  members, including their blind leader Shoko Asahara arrived in Perth on tourist visas on September , and immediately caught the eye of customs officials, according to the Australian Federal Police magazine Platypus.Despite arriving on tourist visas the group had brought with them mining equipment and chemicals including hydrochloric acid in sake bottles and glass jars marked “hand soap”.Detective Leading Senior Constable Mark Creighton told the magazine an AFP officer noted the amount of excess baggage the group was carrying and the jars of acid they claimed were soap.Customs officers seized ammonium chloride, sodium sulphate, perchloric acid and ammonium water, along with laboratory equipment.Creighton said customs became suspicious of the group for other reasons.He said: “Accompanying the group were six or seven Japanese girls who were under the age of .“Their parents werent with them and the thing that struck us at the time was that this might have been child abuse because Banjawarn Station is miles from anywhere.”Despite the suspicions the group were allowed to continue through customs.Arriving at Banjawam Station the group set up a laboratory in the homestead’s kitchen, complete with evaporators, Bunsen burners, beakers, a rock crushing machine and its own generator once the lab had been set up most of the group then flew home.Those members who stayed bought chemicals locally to replace those that had been confiscated as well as earth moving equipment from Kalgoorlie, km south of  the homestead.While all this was going on the AFP were carrying out their own investigation and had contacted the National Police Agency of Japan and received information on the cult as well as Shoko Asahara’s criminal record.Asahara had founded Shinrikyo Aum in Tokyo in  and at its height is said to have had tens of thousands of followers.In  the leader declared himself to be Christ, identying himself as the “Lamb of God”.Among the sect’s strange beliefs and rituals, followers were encouraged to drink ml of Asahara’s bath water, which cost .They were also encouraged to drink his blood which was said to give them enlightenment.He prophesised a third world war, which in his mind would be initiated by the US and which only Aum members would survive.The sect gained international infamy on March ,  when it launched the sarin attack on five Tokyo train stations.The group had sold the homestead the previous August at a loss of , but following the attack, which drew worldwide attention, the new owners of the station contacted local police.Investigators carried out searches and testing at the site, finding evidence of sarin experiments that had been conducted on sheep at the property.They also found evidence the sect had plans to build a nuclear weapon and had used an excavator to dig up uranium.Asahara was executed along with Kiyohide Hayakawa and Yoshihiro Inoue, the pair who had scouted Banjawarn, as well as Seiichi Endo, the so-called head scientist, and nine other sect members in July .Aum Shinrikyo was classied as a terrorist organisation and still exists under the name Aleph.

title: steve coogan furloughs nine staff
story: Seven full-time employees and two temporary staff at Baby Cow Productions are being paid by the taxpayer-funded scheme.The Sun revealed last week millionaire Coogan, , had furloughed the gardener and housekeeper at his £million mansion.The Alan Partridge star left taxpayers to stump up  per cent of the pair’s wages.Baby Cow, behind TV hits including Gavin  Stacey as well as movies such as Stan  Ollie, was founded by Coogan.He now owns some  per cent after selling a stake to BBC Studios, a commercial arm of the BBC, which paid around £million and has given almost £million in income and loans over four years.The firm last month created a managing director role and appointed BBC Studios’ Sarah Monteith.Tory critic Coogan, worth £million, boasted how he had made the firm “fighting fit” and staff had been working hard.But Baby Cow admitted it “has utilised the job retention scheme” for those making the Civil War comedy The Witchfinder.The Commons Treasury committee called his move to furlough personal staff “absolutely wrong” and TV host Piers Morgan branded it “stinking hypocrisy”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Former soldier Ismail Hachem — shot in the back in the war-torn country — said: “We came to England to find safety.How are we supposed to feel safe now Heartbroken Ismail spoke to The Sun on Sunday as he shared a treasured snap of -year-old daughter Aya posing by illuminated angel wings in Manchester.She died last Sunday near their home in Blackburn as she went to get shopping.The family arrived ten years ago. title: teachers extra shifts help kids
story: SIX in  teachers are willing to give up their summer hols to help struggling kids, it has emerged.School staff want to get back into the classroom in July and August to help boost grades for disadvantaged kids affected by the coronavirus crisis.Summer camps are already being worked on by officials in Whitehall as  per cent of teachers are willing to put in extra shts, a survey has found.The findings come as the National Education Union indicated they are willing to speed up talks with the Government — which hopes to have schools open from next Monday.More than , teachers took part in the poll which showed the majority wanted to reduce their time off to help pupils “get back on track”.Charity Teach First has called on catch-up camps to be launched over the summer as long as social distancing measures allow it.The move would allow children from disadvantaged backgrounds to reduce the attainment gap caused by being away from the classroom.Thirty-two per cent of teachers willing to take part would give up a week of their summer break while  per cent would give up more.The majority of those prepared to give up some of their six-week break would want to be paid overtime.Analysis shows that pupils who attend summer school make a staggering two months additional progress compared to those who don’t.This can even increase to four monthsthe courses are intensive and run by experienced teachers.Teach First CEO Russell Hobby said: “Many schools will be cautiously opening to more pupils this summerthe evidence says it is safe.“But some children may be out of school until September and many children in lower income families have limited access to internet or devices to learn from home.“We think there is a strong case for one or two weeks of intensive provision for those who need it most, either during the summer or even into the Autumn, so that teachers can see pupils to check how they are and help them get ready for learning again.“This will help to ensure pupils can make a good start when schools fully open again.“We cannot allow a generation of pupils to fall behind on their education.“We must do whatever we can to support schools serving the pupils who need us and not let this generation be left behind.”Tory MP Robert Halfon said the idea of summer schools was a “no-brainer” for the government.He said: “Coronavirus could lead to a decade of educational poverty and a huge safeguarding crisis for vulnerable children.“Summer school which allows for catch-up lessons and mentoring will make all the dference.”The Sun on Sunday revealed last week that the gap in performance of Britain’s poorest pupils has been set back a decade since the lockdown — mainly due to not having internet access at home.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has already tasked his officials to work on plans for catch-up camps during the summer break.He revealed “initiatives” are being looked at to be rolled out to help with lost lessons since schools closed for most students in March.However, he said that there are “no plans” for schools to re-open in full over the summer months.The Scientic Advisory Group on Emergencies has said a track and trace system must be in place before schools are allowed to open.Ministers hope to bring back Reception, Year  and Year  on June .The remaining primary school pupils couldon June  for a month before terms end.LIKE every other parent in the country, I’ve spent the last few months grappling with some unexpected homeschooling.Even though I’m a former teacher with years of experience under my belt, it’s not been easy. Juggling my work with that of four daughters aged six to  is a challenge. We’re the lucky ones, too, with plenty of space, devices, and so on.Many families don’t have these advantages, and so their children face an uphill struggle to keep up with those who do. Right now millions of kids are falling behind their advantaged classmates, for reasons completely out of their control, and in spite of their parents’ best efforts.The past decade has seen good progress in closing the learning gap between children. Common sense reforms have allowed all kids to benefit from better discipline, richer curriculums, and tougher exams, but those from more deprived backgrounds have benefitted most.However, the coronavirus crisis is putting these gains and more at risk, even though our teachers have performed near-miracles during lockdown.With minimal warning and no extra money, they went from educating and safeguarding millions of children in classrooms to doing so remotely.They did all this while keeping schools open to children at risk and those of key workers, and looking after their own children at home too! We should all be immensely proud of this.Nothing beats being in a class with a great teacher, though. It’s why I’m so keen that kids get back to school as soon as possible, and for the teaching unions to stop blocking this.It’s also why I love the idea of catch-up summer schools during the summer holidays.I can think of loads of reasons why dferent children would benefit from being in school for some or all of the holiday period. Some might need academic support in key subjects. Others might have faced particular traumas during lockdown and need pastoral support or counselling.It could be as simple as wanting to get back into some kind of routine with familiar faces outside of their immediate family. And of course, having access to summer school would make it easier for many families to get in or back to work as we kickstart the economy in this strange new world.Butwe’re going to make it all work we must use our common sense. We should keep things optional, flexible, and fully-funded.It must be optional for teachers and pupils. Staff have been busier than ever. Kids and their families will want to enjoy any freedoms from lockdown by then. A decent break is vital to ensure everyone is refreshed for a challenging start to the school year in September.However I’m confident though that there will still be enough staff - and community volunteers - for summer catch-up. And schools are perfectly placed to get in the kids who need it most.But we shouldn’t expect it to run like normal school. These are not normal times and we won’t have all the usual staff to hand. We have to work around these, and the needs of the children that come in.And that’s why it must be properly funded by the government. If it’s worth doing, it’s worth doing well, and asking people to give up their summer to pull together something of quality will cost.Get it right though, and catch-up summer schools could make all the dference to kids and families in a time of need. It would also be another great example of the dference schools can make when times are tough.Where can I sign up !To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: portuguese rapper mota jr suspects fled
story: European arrest warrants had already been issued for the pair after cops discovered they had fled to the UK following David Mota’s brutal killing, local paper Correio da Manha said.Today, it also emerged the -year-old, who flaunted a “billionaire lestyle” with fans online, had spent part of his childhood in Britain.The UK connection to the grisly crime came after an initial post-mortem pointed to the musician, known as Mota Jr, being kicked and punched to death.Police are working on the theory he was killed after being kidnapped and tortured by a trio who wanted to steal his jewels and cash.Mota, the youngest of three children, was born in Portugal but moved to London when he was  after his dad, who was already working in the UK, was diagnosed with leukaemia.He vanished on March  after being abducted outside his home in Sintra near Lisbon.His decomposed body, which had been partly eaten by wild boars, was found on Monday in woods near Sesimbra  miles away by a man out walking his dog.Two of the suspects reportedly fled to the UK the week after the crime, thought to have been planned by an acquaintance of Mota Jr who is known to police.The names of the suspects have begun to circulate on social media but have not been published by local media.No-one from Portugal’s Policia Judiciaria police force could be reached for comment this morning.Mota Jr was known to flaunt gold jewellery and wads of cash on social media.One of the photos posted to his , followers on Instagram before he went missing showed him lying on a bed surrounded by  euro notes with a wad of  and  euro notes in his hand.In others he showed off expensive sports cars and in the company of scantily-clad women.The suspects reportedly ed to his home the day after the rapper’s disappearance to steal his gold and money while his family were at a nearby police station giving statements.They are said to have let themselves in a with a key they stole from their victim after he confessed under duress where he kept his valuables.Police have ruled out the theory his death was linked to a “rapper war” despite investigating claims of problems between rival musicians.Mota Jr’s mum Filomena has told Portuguese media she believes his attackers intended to rob him but not kill him.Police have already interviewed a friend of the dead rapper’s who says she was threatened by David’s attackers who told her to leave the area after they put a weapon to his head.The rappers mum Filomena told local news outlet TVI how she received an early-hours call from a neighbour saying she had found David’s flip-flops and cap in the entrance hall to the block of flats where he lived with his family.She said: “I went to check on David and he wasn’t in his bedroom like I thought he was.“I’d heard the front door shut earlier but thought it was a friend he’d been with who was leaving.“When I went downstairs after the neighbour’s call, I discovered specks of blood on the floor by the lt and I called the police.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: harry meghan finding freedom leaving royals
story: Finding Freedom - said to have been written with the couple’s knowledge - will shatter the notion the American actress is the driving force behind the pair.A large section of the biography will be dedicated to “setting the record straight” over Megxit.On Saturday night a publishing insider said: “That word ‘Megxit’ in particular has always angered Prince Harry. It gives the impression that the decision to walk away from the Royal Family was Meghan’s.“The reality is Harry drove that decision. The book will make that clear and explain why it had to happen. The truth is Harry had been unhappy for a long, long time.“He wanted to move in the direction that they did and had been considering it for more than a year.“Meghan supported Harry’s decision. But there was more than one occasion where she asked himhe was certain it was what he wanted.“And she always made it clear she would support him in whatever he did.”In the days after his shock announcement that he was stepping away from Royal le, Harry, , hinted at his anger that the finger had been pointed at his we for the decision.Speaking at a charity event he said: “Once Meghan and I were married, we were excited, we were hopeful, and we were here to serve.“For those reasons, it brings me great sadness that it has come to this. The decision that I have made for my we and I to step back, is not one I made lightly.“It was so many months of talks after so many years of challenges. And I know I haven’t always gotten it right, but as far as this goes, there really was no other option.”Contrary to reports, the book - published worldwide on August  - will not be detailing the  year old Suits star’s ongoing fallout with her dad Thomas.The source added: “The book - as the very woke title suggests - is very much about the ‘journey’ Meghan and Harry are embarking on.“It will focus closely on the causes Meghan and Harry want to focus on, and the new le they are leading.“The book won’t address things that have been said about them by Thomas . This matter is being dealt with in court and that’s where Harry and Meghan think it should stay.”According to publishers, Finding Freedom: Harry and Meghan and the Making of a Modern Royal Family, goes ‘beyond the headlines’.It will ‘dispel the many rumours and misconceptions which have plagued the couple on both sides of the pond.’The -page tome is said to be an “honest, up-close, and disarming portrait of a confident, influential, and forward-thinking couple who are unafraid to break with tradition, determined to create a new path away from the spotlight, and dedicated to building a humanitarian legacy that will make a profound dference in the world.”The authors - former showbiz journalist Omid Scobie and royal reporter Carolyn Durand - are said to have been given access to friends of the pair, as well as direct access to the Sussexes themselves.News of the biography comes after the Duke and Duchess announced they would be having a “zero engagement” policy with British tabloids.Meanwhile, earlier this week the couple celebrated their second wedding anniversary - enjoying Zoom calls with family including Meghan’s mum, Doria, and block booking a day off work.We can reveal they also enjoyed a takeaway dinner from one of the star’s favourite Los Angeles restaurants, Baco Mercat.Prepared by the eaterie’s head chef, they washed down their ‘Mexican-Mediterranean’-themed supper - £ beef bacos and £. stuffed flatbreads - with margaritas.According to a family friend, the pair were also sent a bottle of celebratory vintage wine from pals George and Amal Clooney.The source added: “It was a lovely, low-key day and night, and baby Archie was with them throughout.“For her gt to him, Meghan had an artist friend of Doria’s design a print which included the lyrics to the first dance from their wedding, which she then had framed. It was both thoughtful and romantic.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: coronavirus sweden herd immunity study
story: The Swedish study found just . per cent of people in the capital Stockholm had developed Covid- antibodies by late April.The country’s controversial policy of not implementing a lockdown during the coronavirus outbreak was championed by Chief Epidemiologist Anders Tegnell, who recommended voluntary measures instead.Instead of restricting people’s movements and shutting down businesses and bars Sweden kept places open.The country’s death rates have been far higher than its Scandinavian counterparts but still lower than some European countries such as Britain, France and Italy, which implemented a lockdown at the height of the outbreak.Health authorities in Sweden now say the outbreak is slowing as the number of patients in intensive care has dropped by a third from a peak in late April.But over the past seven days Sweden has recorded the highest number of deaths per capita from Covid- in Europe.The study examined the potential of herd immunity to effectively stop the disease from spreading in the community.According to the Swedish Health Agency on Wednesday, the findings were roughly in line with models predicting a third of the Swedish capitals population would have had the virus by now and where at least limited herd immunity could have been established.Tegnell said: “It is a little bit lowerbut not remarkably lower, maybe one or a couple of percent. It squares pretty well with the models we have.”He had previously predicted Sweden would have herd immunity by May.The study examined around , tests from across the country but only figures from Stockholm were published.Health Agency officials stressed though that herd immunity was not a goal in itself but a strategy to slow the virus spreading enough so that health workers could cope, rather than suppress it completely.They added countries which had implemented a lockdown faced the potential for a second outbreak to flare up.The World Health Organisationhas warned against a herd immunity policy.It said last week studies from around the world had found antibodies in only - percent of the population, results in line with recent findings in Spain and France.Professor of Infectious Medicine at Uppsala University Bjorn Olsen has been a critic of Sweden’s response to the pandemic, calling it a “dangerous and unrealistic” approach to dealing with Covid-.He said after the findings had been released: “I think herd immunity is a long way off,we ever reach it.”Coronavirus testing in Sweden has largely been restricted to hospitalised cases and health care workers with weekly testing running at less than a third of the government’s target of ,, well below that of most western European countries.Helen Gluckman, , wept  as she related how her -year-old father died of a Covid- infection contracted in a nursing home after untested patients were admitted there.She said: We dont know what will happen when other countries open up, but right now one cant help but think Sweden has really failed.“There are more than , dead now. That is a horrible number.”The number of recorded cases in Sweden has now broken the , mark with , deaths, more than three times the combined total of Denmark, Norway, Finland and Iceland.Olsen says Sweden has done “too little, too late”.Critics also say the government’s policy has been catastrophic for the elderly.The government has defended its policy saying Swedens per capita death toll, which is now the highest in the world, did not result from the lack of a national lockdown.Health and Social Affairs Minister Lena Hellengren said most Swedes had voluntarily minimised their social interactions and movements outside the home.She said: “The Swedes have really changed their behaviour.”

title: open air activities to reopen from june
story: The PM will ease restrictions on open-air activities in the latest step on the road back to normal le.Mr Johnson is expected to give the go-ahead for market stalls, car sales centres and garden fetes from next month.National Trust parks will also be told they can open for business providing indoor attractions remain out of bounds.Even some non-essential shops could be given the all-clear to open again. Mr Johnson wants to salvage the summer for families confined for the past nine weeks.And he is keen to make the countryside accessible again — but in “slow steps”.A senior Government source said: “It is clear from the scientic evidence that the rate of infection is much less likely outdoors. The combination of fresh air and sunshine are bad for the virus but they make it safer for everyone.“So we are looking at opening up the outdoors. But all done in slow steps.“Social distancing must continue andthere’s the slightest hint of the infection rate rising again, or people hanging around in large groups, the PM will call a halt.”The insider cautioned: “We will need to adjust to a new normal, and we must stay alert to the dangers of a further spread.”The PM will update ministers on Monday at a Cabinet meeting on precisely which sectors will be unlocked first.He will host the Downing Street press conference on Thursday to announce summer has been saved.The source said: “The PM has spent much time lately focused on gripping control of the machine.“There were things he wasn’t happy with, so for the past couple of weeks he has been under the bonnet, making sure that everything is well-oiled and ready to run smoothly.”Guidance will be issued to shops and attractions that will resume business in step two of his road map back to “near-normal”, starting on June .Mr Johnson will also disclose details of his new “world-beating” test, track and trace system aimed at defeating coronavirus in a “whack-a-mole” assault.He will demand more tests are carried out so infected people can be isolated.The Government has recruited an army of contact tracers that will soon be mobile.The team will contact those who tested positive and find out who they have been in contact with so they too can be tested.Mr Johnson will this week provide full details on the actions they will need to take to make the system work. But Chancellor Rishi Sunak has voiced frustration over the pace of the unlocking.He is increasingly anxious about the damage from the lack of economic activity and the cost of furloughing workers.Mr Sunak suggested to Tory MPs in a conference call that the PM was being too cautious, saying said: “Somehow Greece and Italy are opening up. This country can’t be the only place where people can’t go and have a drink in the pub.”But Mr Johnson is unlikely to give the all-clear to pubs and restaurants this week.He is considering letting outdoor cafes resume business with strict limits on table spacing and numbers. But he has resisted calls for department stores to reopen.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Netflix four-part series ‘Filthy Rich promises’ exposes how the multi-millionaire sex offender used his wealth and power to carry out his sickening campaign of abuse.Epstein, , hanged himself in a New York jail while awaiting trial on sex-trafficking charges.Prosecutors said he amassed a “vast network” of girls as young as  who he would lure to his homes and sexually abuse.The documentary goes into detail about how Epstein was able to lure girls to abuse and hears from victims who say they were paid to recruit other victims.It details how a pattern emerged of one friend recruiting two friends who in turn recruited another two friends.Attorney Brad Edwards represents victim Courtney Wild, who he met after the FBI started investigating Epstein, and started building a case against the sex offender.In the documentary he explains his team assembled flow chart of victims in about  days but realized it could end up being five times as big as the poster board it was on.We had to prove that this pyramid of underage girls in Palm Beach was true, said Edwards.It didnt start from just a random underage girl walking into the house.Haley Robson initially refused Epsteins initial advances, but he told her thatshe brought her friends over, hed give her .She said she probably recruited  underage girls who were mostly her friends and classmates, to go to Epsteins house.The documentary also describes how Epstein, with the assistance of his partner Ghislaine Maxwell preyed on them.Maxwell has vehemently denied any wrongdoing.Some were offered financial or career assistance and put up in lavish accommodation.That in turn led to the girls not wanting to seem ungrateful when he later made sexual advances.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: titanic salvage mission ten items
story: Now,  years on, relic hunters have won permission from a US judge to search the wreck and retrieve the device. It is believed the Marconi radio — used by operator Jack Phillips with morse code — will help add to the ­Belfast-built liner’s legacy.Until now a joint UK-US treaty protected the ship from exploitation because it is a mass grave.But controversially, American firm RMS Titanic Inc, which already owns items of the ship’s memorabilia, can now send up to three unmanned robots down to the ruin, ,ft below the waves of the Atlantic.The Titanic sank in April , ­killing , people, after hitting an ­iceberg, and Dr Robert Blyth, senior ­curator at the National Maritime Museum in ­Green­wich, South East London, wants the vessel left alone.He says it would reveal little we do not already know about the disaster.He said: “Preserving the site as a memorial to the dead and monitoring the gradual disappearance of the wreck would seem the most respectful way of remembering the Titanic.”TV documentary maker Robert Strange, who carried out extensive research while writing his book Who Sank The Titanic  The Final Verdict, said: “It should be left untouched.”With thousands of items already having been recovered from the ship, TV expert Robert has drawn up a list of ten objects still inside the wreck that he would like to see salvaged.Chief baker Charles Joughin sent his  bakers to the leboats with four loaves each to “provision” the vessels and helped third-class passengers to the boat deck.He refused a place in the le rafts and ed to his cabin, gulped several large whiskies and, despite being drunk, somehow got into the water and survived.One of his duties was “sounding the ship” by throwing a lead weight on a line into water in the bilges.He was probably the first person to realise the Titanic was doomed and was last seen wandering the corridors holding his weight, trying to report to the captain.When billionaire Astor’s drowned body was recovered, his effects were listed as a gold watch, gold and diamond cufflinks, a three-stone diamond ring, and around , US dollars.Astor, who owned a fabulous collection of watches, rings and other jewellery, must have left a lot behind in his cabin.This was used by -year-old able seaman Frederick Fleet to warn that he had spotted an iceberg.“I got an answer straight away,” he later told the Titanic inquiry. “I reported it as soon as I saw it . . . an iceberg straight ahead.”A copy of the Titanic’s Board of Trade Passenger Certicate, signed by a ­surveyor after a sea trial on April , , remains on board.This certied the ship safe to carry passengers, despite the hurried final construction.The first-class gym on board included an electric camel-riding machine for wealthy passengers.In an age of female delicacy, it was reportedly “popular with the ladies”.Any coal shovel from the bowels of the engine room, where crewmen laboured in darkness and danger to keep the ship’s ­generators operating, despite the rising water in the boiler rooms. The death toll was highest among these brave men.Each boiler room had a colour-coded warning-lights system – white for full speed, blue for slow and red for stop. On the night of the disaster, the doors began closing and the red lights came on. Leading stoker Frederick ­Barrett was first to react and order, “Close all dampers” to cut air to the boiler fires.The only Frenchman among the musicians who reportedly played to the end to try to keep passengers calm.Aged just  when he drowned, Roger’s body was never recovered.Mining tycoon Ben was always immaculately dressed – complete with gold tie pin. Having helped his mistress into a leboat, he reputedly waited for death with other first-class passengers, popped a rose into his buttonhole, and said: “We’ve dressed up in our best and are ­prepared to go down like gentlemen.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china coronavirus cover up 5g
story: EVEN before the Covid- outbreak, China faced criticism of its policies across the globe.Its failure to observe World Trade Organization rules on subsidy, dumping and intellectual property theft contributed to a trade war with the US.Security fears in the South China Sea were heightened as China ignored international law, while simmering tensions over Beijing’s treatment of Hong Kong fuelled doubts about the value of its treaty obligations.Now, following the spread of coronavirus around the world, China faces new allegations on its charge sheet.These centre on the fact China was aware of a new virus from the middle of November — but did not inform the World Health Organization until the end of December.There are allegations that laboratory workers there were ordered to DESTROY samples of the virus, while whistleblowers were threatened and silenced.Perhaps most seriously, throughout January authorities denied human-to-human transmission was possible — even though since late December they knew it was happening.On January , despite this knowledge, the authorities in Wuhan allowed a massive banquet for , families to go ahead.To make matters worse, the mayor of Wuhan subsequently revealed that five million residents left the city before the lockdown.The world needs to understand the origins of the virus, including any human-to-animal interface, to help prevent future recurrence and guide public health policy.Research shows thatChina had acted between a week and three weeks earlier, the number of cases could have been reduced by between  and  per cent.One study, using data from Chinese tech giant Tencent, suggests that before travel restrictions were put in place,  per cent of coronavirus cases went undocumented.As international travel was still permitted at that time, this helps to explain the speed with which the virus spread around the world.China’s ruling Communist Party reacted to the crisis with the denial and repression common to every totalitarian state. Iran, for example, has deployed a similar strategy.For years, we have known China censors what its people read and say online. Now we know authorities began censoring keywords and discussion of the outbreak weeks before its severity was acknowledged.Already in late December, doctors in Wuhan began to see patients suffering from an unusual pneumonia.Dr Li Wenliang,  who reported it to colleagues, was forced by police to sign a confession denouncing his communication as “illegal behaviour”.Dr Li later “died of the outbreak”.A number of critical journalists then went missing, along with Ren Zhiqiang, a well-known property tycoon critical of the regime.A month after his disappearance, China announced his official detention and investigation.Beijing is now saying that it will allow the WHO to visit for an investigation — but “not yet”.So how should we deal with China going forwards — especially since an inept, repressive officialdom has responded to international criticism with an aggressive misinformation campaign, completely misjudging the mood around the world China, as the world’s second-biggest economy, will remain an important export market for our goods and services.Even the Trump administration in the US does not want to close off a lucrative market for American farmers.It needs to abide by global rulesAs Trade Secretary, I tried to build a constructive relationship with my Chinese counterparts to help our businesses sell more to them and support jobs here.ButChina wants to be a partner in the global trading system, it needs to abide by global rules.This will be a major challenge as we face the inevitable task of reforming the World Trade Organization. When it comes to our national security, as The Sun on Sunday so clearly set out in recent weeks, we cannot afford to have it linked to other economic or political considerations.That is why I, along with a number of fellow MPs, voted against the Government’s plans to include Chinese tech firm Huawei in our G data network.China is at a crossroads and needs to decide whether it truly wants to become a partner in the global community or take the path to becoming a pariah state.That choice is in their hands. Our national security lies in ours.We all hope China will make the necessary reforms and take the right path.But hope is not a good basis for foreign policy. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
