title: dominic cummings lockdown critics no10
story: DOMINIC Cummings has left the door wide open for Number ’s critics.As Boris Johnson’s key adviser, he was an architect of the lockdown that has kept us all behind doors for weeks on end.So most people are shocked to find he drove  miles to his parents’ home in the first days of lockdown while his we was ill with Covid- and he himself was showing symptoms.Mr Cummings knows the level of scrutiny he is under and that he has to be seen to be beyond reproach. By doing this he has left himself open to claims that he behaves asthere is one law for him and one law for the rest of us.But his case is very dferent to those of Professor Neil Ferguson and Scotland’s chief medical officer, Catherine Calderwood, who both resigned after breaking lockdown.Professor Ferguson went to visit his married lover and Dr Calderwood enjoyed a break at her holiday home.Mr Cummings travelled to isolate himself and ensure the protection of his young son. He was a sick man doing what he thought was best.However, his trip to Durham has ended up with Labour MPs, his Brexit enemies and many frustrated lockdown families demanding he resign.Mr Cummings is credited with having the Government’s biggest brain.It’s time he started using it.THE coronavirus crisis is a blight on our children’s education.So it is heartening that a majority of teachers say they want to help pupils who have slipped behind with schools shut.A poll has found that  per cent would willingly give up some of their summer holidays to teach those who need it.Week-long summer schools can help disadvantaged children catch up by a staggering two months or more.Militant union bosses set on sabotaging next month’s reopening of schools will no doubt rattle their sabres.But the Government should unveil an extensive summer school scheme.An army of teachers is ready and we owe it to the next generation.“THIS country can’t be the only place in the world where people can’t go out and get a drink in the pub.”Not our words, but those of Rishi Sunak.We couldn’t agree more, Chancellor.Anything you can do would be much appreciated.Britain deserves a pub pint!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kim jong un reappears again health
story: The North Korean leader, , vanished for  days last month before turning up on May  at a newly-constructed fertiliser plant before again disappearing from public.Now, the secretive kingdoms propaganda news agency has released images of the dictator speaking at a conference of the Central Military Committee of the Workers Party of Korea.He hosted the meeting to discuss new policies to bolster the countrys nuclear capabilities, state media KCNA said.Set forth at the meeting were new policies for further increasing the nuclear war deterrence of the country and putting the strategic armed forces on a high alert operation, KCNA said.However, the pictures have not been independently veried.Following his first disappearing act, reports emerged claiming the despot had died or was gravely ill after a botched heart operation.South Korea officials say they believe the coronavirus pandemic which has swept the world may be linked to his recent lack of public appearances.Citing an unnamed government official, JoongAng Ilbo newspaper reported Kim may be carrying out his duties from his lavish villa in Wonsan, on the countrys eastern coast.North Korea still denies it has a single case of Covid-.Since May , state media has carried a steady stream of stories on Kim sending or receiving letters and diplomatic correspondence, but have not shown him attending public events.Kims longest public absence was for  days in  when he is believed to have undergone a medical procedure on his ankle.This comes as Kims Supreme Commander emblem has been erased from state TV, according to title: girl smells gas saves street
story: Aoe Dean alerted mum Sian Drew and partner John Pearse, , telling them the house had a funny smell.When the family from St Helens, Merseyside, realised the strange smell was gas, they contacted gas engineers who traced the smell to a neighbouring home where a cooker had been left on for  hours.A year later, on the anniversary of Aoe’s lesaving actions, mum Sian is sharing the story for the first time to raise awareness of the dangers of gas explosions.Sian, , said: “She’s a hero. She saved the whole street - were completely made up with her.“If the gas had caused an explosion, the damage could have been extraordinary.After arriving at the familys house at around am, a gas engineer managed to wake all the neighbours.Sian said: “The gas man said that it had built up to a level that eventhe neighbour had turned their light on and created a spark, it could’ve caused an explosion.Aoe was given a certicate from the gas company and a handwritten letter thanking her for her heroic actions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus vaccine oxford university discovery 50 chance
story: BRITAIN’S leading scientist in the hunt to find a coronavirus vaccine has warned that there is only a  per cent chance of success.Professor Adrian Hill, who heads a team of experts at Oxford University, said the chances of discovering a vaccine were being rapidly reduced as Covid- cleared up.Pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca announced this week a .billion deal with the US government to produce million doses of an unproved coronavirus vaccine, dubbed ZD, which was first produced in Prof Hill’s lab.The British government has also agreed to pay for up to m doses, saying some m may be ready for UK citizens by September.Any vaccine would allow countries to lt any lockdown restrictions, allow people toto work and get the economy moving again.But Prof Hill, who is director of the university’s Jenner Institute, has said that because the virus is rapidly disappearing it reduces the chances of success.With the country in lockdown this reduces the spread of the disease, making it harder for scientist to prove their vaccine has an impact.Prof Hill, , told The Sunday : “It is a race, yes. But its not a race against the other guys. Its a race against the virus disappearing, and against time.“We said earlier in the year that there was an  per cent chance of developing an effective vaccine by September.“But at the moment, there’s a  per cent chance that we get no result at all.“We’re in the bizarre position of wanting Covid to stay, at least for a little while. But cases are declining.He said that of the , people who had been recruited to test the vaccine – some who will be given an placebo – he expected fewer than  people to catch the virus.But he warned thatfewer than  test positive, then the results may be useless.Prof Hill added: “I wouldn’t book a holiday in October on the back of these announcements, put it that way.”Business Secretary Alok Sharma suggested half the UK population could be given the jab this autumn,the trial was a success, at a Downing Street press conference on May .Prof Hill warned: “There’s a danger of over-promising here. This is the way I usually say it: this is our ambition. There are multiple risks. Its never been done before. We dont knowwe can do it. We think we can.The results of an earlier trial conducted by the Oxford team are due to be released early next month when , volunteers took part in a test in April, during the peak of the pandemic.The Oxford researchers are just one of eight human trials for a potential Covid- vaccine.There are four in China, two in the US and one in Germany in addition to the one in Oxford.The Oxford team has already arranged for further trials to take place in the US and are also currently in talks with other countries where the virus is still spreading.Prof Hill’s current research is based on his earlier search for a vaccine to combat malaria.Over two decades researchers at the Jenner Institute worked out how to alter the genetic code of a familiar virus, first to neutralise its harmful effects and then to make it imitate a deadlier disease.The harmless virus is then injected into the bloodstream which causes the body to produce an immune response which gives long-lasting protection.While there has not yet been a malaria vaccine, a colleague of Prof Hill, Professor Sarah Gilbert was able to mody the same chimpanzee virus to vaccinate against MERS, a coronavirus, which then progressed onto human trials in the UK.When Covid- began to spread, Prof Gilbert carried out a project to seethe Oxford technique could work on the new disease and tests in April on six rhesus macaque monkeys found that after being exposed to the disease all were healthy a month later.Should the next phase of human trials be a success the Government has said the “people in the UK will get the first access, helping to protect thousands of lives”.

title: ramadan mubarak kareem maradan 2020 meaning
story: The phrases have dferent meanings and are used at dferent times.Happy Ramadan can be translated to Ramadan Mubarak, which also means blessed Ramadan.Ramadan Kareem means may Ramadan be generous to you but there is some debate as toit should be used during Ramadan.The greetings are dferent as Ramadan Mubarak offers a blessed or happy Ramadan to the person it is exchanged with.Whereas Ramadan Kareem has debate around its use as it asks Ramadan to be generous to the other person.Saudi Arabian scholar Sheikh Al-Uthaymeen told the Express: “It should be said ‘Ramadan Mubarak’, or whatever is similar to it, because it is not Ramadan itself that gives so that it can be kareem , in fact it is Allah who placed the grace in it, and made it a special month, and a time to perform one of the pillars of Islam.”Ramadan Mubarak is the most commonly used of the two as it was originally used by the prophet Muhammad.However, others believe using Ramadan Kareem is fine because they say the phrase represents the blessings that Allah gives his followers during the month.Both greetings can be used throughout the whole month of Ramadan but Ramadan Mubarak tends to be the more commonly used of the two.Typically, the start of the month is welcomed with greetings such as Ramadan Mubarak.On the last day of Ramadan, which is Eid-al-fitr, the greeting changes to Eid Mubarak.The last day of Ramadan in  will be May .Traditionally, Ramadan begins with the sighting of the crescent moon, which usually appears one night after the new moon, meaning the start date cant be predicted.Eid al-Fitr works in exactly the same way.The sighting of the new crescent moon brings the end of Ramadan and the onset of the month of Shawwal, the tenth of the Islamic Hijri calendar.There is debate as to whether the idea of a moon sighting should refer to you physically witnessing the moon where you are, which could be dictated by factors such as the weather, or whether to defer to sightings in Saudi Arabia or other regions.Ramadan, the ninth month in the Islamic calendar, is a period of fasting observed by Muslims across the globe to celebrate the best of times.It celebrates the first time the Koran was revealed to Muhammad, according to Islamic belief.Fasting is only obligatory for healthy adult Muslims, anyone who is suffering from an illness, travelling, elderly, pregnant, breastfeeding, diabetic, chronically ill or menstruating are exempt from the practice.The fasting period, during which Muslims are not allowed to eat or drink, is from dawn to sunset and Muslims engage in increased prayer activity.Muslims often try and practice an increased self-discipline during the month of Ramadan.In  Ramadan started on the evening of Thursday, April  and ends in the evening of Saturday, May title: coronavirus money help national lottery
story: AdvertorialThe National Lotterys £m coronavirus funding - heres how its being shared outThanks to National Lottery players, £m is being used to support good causes across the UKShareByDave Masters:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Advertorial" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailYou might not know it, but you’re giving a lockdown leline to hundreds of thousands of people across the UK. You’re helping to tackle loneliness and isolation. You’re providing meals to people that cannot leave home. You’re helping fund projects that support physical and mental health in communities across the entire nation.We’re facing exceptional times brought about by the coronavirus pandemic.But thanks to you, £ million of funding from The National Lottery is being distributed over the next few months to charities, projects and good causes. This vital funding has helped hundreds of key projects continue to offer support to people in our communities.  One of those to benefit is Northern Ireland’s Macular Society, which helps people struggling with their sight due to macular degeneration. They provide peer support, counselling, help, advice and many other services to members. The charity received an additional £, grant from The National Lottery to adapt and increase support for people remotely during lockdown. Elaine Orwinhas been involved with the charity for  years. The -year-old said: Macular disease affects your physical health. You often can’t drive so lose your independence, but our group of  members is a leline. We used to meet monthly, but since lockdown it’s fortnightly virtual meetings, and I’ve also referred people for phone counselling. The contact we have had is really precious.  The charity is planning to launch a befriending service and webinars, and they’ve also run a Tech Talk project, helping members to use computers and even just access audio description on their TVs. It’s really important for us to thank National Lottery players, as without them none of this would be possible. Another project to receive funding is Leicester’s Emerald Centre, which supports vulnerable people of all ages, including elderly residents and those with disabilities, in a deprived area of the city.  Chris Murphy , , who lives alone, says the charity has kept him in touch with friends during this dficult time. He explained: The centre has been bringing me a food parcel every week. They stop for a chat when it’s delivered and phone to check I’m okay. I love working in my garden so they’ve sent me bits for that, and there’s also been activity packs and books I’ve borrowed from them. It’s all keeping me busy! It’s great that people are playing The National Lottery and helping us. Merthyr Tydfil’s Twyn Community Hubhas also received support, with a £, grant from The National Lottery to expand their daily hot meals and weekly hamper project during lockdown. The charity helps families and vulnerable, older people, with everything from weekly food parcels to organising bingo nights and quizzes.  Jean Jonesis someone who benefits regularly from their work. The -year-old said: I’ve been going to events including bingo at Twyn Community Hub since moving here nearly six years ago, and throughout lockdown staff and volunteers have been popping round most days to deliver food, and have a chat. I’m lucky in that I phone friends and family, but other older people in the area would see no one otherwise. The meals and food they provide are fabulous. Being able to take away the worry about small, practical, everyday things is so important. Thanks to people playing The National Lottery that is happening right here in our local area. Itaposs thanks to National Lottery players, as well as the people who run these vital services, that these sorts of charities and local projects have been able to continue offering support to the most vulnerable people in our communities.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A vow to put Brits firstwe win the race to find a vaccine for the coronavirus could end up leaving us out in the cold­another country beats us to it, ­campaigners warn.Business Secretary Alok Sharma promised the UK would have access to the first jabsa serum developed by Oxford University scientists ­becomes the world leader. But as tests continue, it is not yet certain that will be the case – and the minister’s vow could set back NHS access to a vaccine developed where, according to Medecins Sans Frontieres. Research and policy officer Roz Scourse said: “There’s no guarantee that the Oxford vaccine will be the one. What happensit’s not,you’re saying things like that  “That nationalistic view is something we’re really concerned about. We’re also hearing similar noises in the US. “We don’t know where the ­effective products are going to come from – we all need to commit to sharing now, becauseit comes from another country, the UK risks not having access to it.” The medical charity raised fears after the UK and US resisted plans for a “patent pool” that would mean sharing a successful vaccine between countries so anyone could manufacture the successful formula. Mr Sharma made his comments in a No briefing last week after AstraZeneca signed a deal to manufacture the Oxford vaccine. He said the UK would have access to the vaccines first but would also ensure it would be ­available to developing nations “at the lowest possible cost”. MSF also said the UK has failed to attach conditions to vaccine ­development funds given to pharma firms, to prevent them from profiteering on any drugs they develop. Ms Scource said: “The public is paying twice for this system – once for funding research and development, again when pharma companies are getting the patent. Unless you’re attaching conditions, this is what’s going to happen. High prices could cripple health budgets.” These fears were echoed by Diarmuid McDonald of campaign group Just Treatment, which last year helped force a pharma firm to drop the price of cystic fibrosis drugs the NHS had said it could not afford.  AstraZeneca has promised not to make a profit during the pandemic. But Mr McDonald said: “There’s a chance we’ll have to vaccinate millions of people every year. If we start seeing AstraZeneca at that point charging high prices, that turns into billions of pounds a year for the NHS every year.” A Government spokesman said: “We are clear that any successful vaccine must be available globally, to give us the best chance of stopping this pandemic. “That is why the UK is the biggest donor to the efforts of the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations to find a vaccine.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDominic Cummings is under huge pressure to explain TWO trips which defied lockdown rules HE helped draw up. Boris Johnson’s top aide was spotted in Houghall Woods a fortnight after the first sighting. He was first spotted in Durham on April  while self isolating with the coronavirus. Ato London saw him back at work on April . But by April  he was back in Durham. On the second visit, fellow walkers spotted Mr Cummings at the local beauty spot. The adviser – tonight facing growing calls to quit – claimed Mr Cummings commented as he passed by: “Aren’t the bluebells lovely ”  The revelations came as:A YouGov poll showed  per cent of people think he broke the rules and  per cent think he should resign. Mr Johnson - under growing pressure to sack him – reiterated his support. A tetchy Mr Cummings clashed with press outside his home, insisting: “It’s a question of doing the right thing. It’s not about what you guys think.”The Government was thrown into chaos yesterday after we reported that the PM’s chief-of-staff broke lockdown rules.  Downing Street said he had needed his relatives in the North East to help with childcare after he and his we Mary Wakefield fell ill. But the claims were mired in confusion after it emerged the couple continued to look after their four-year-old son themselves in Durham. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries cast further doubt when she told the No  daily briefing today that the only exception to the rules wasthere was “an extreme risk to le”. A joint investigation by the Sunday Mirror and Observer can reveal that Mr Cummings was spotted for a second time apparently breaching the rules – after he had recovered from Covid-. It comes as the number of Britons to die from the virus rose by  yesterday to ,. A local couple, who did not want to be named, reported seeing Mr Cummings on Sunday April . One told the Mirror: “We were shocked and surprised to see him because the last time we did was earlier in the week in Downing Street. “We thought ‘He’s not supposed to be here during the lockdown’. We thought ‘What double standards, one rule for him as a senior adviser to the Prime Minister and another for the rest of us’.” The witness said Mr Cummings, wearing his trademark beanie hat and outdoor clothes, was walking with a woman believed to be his we Mary. The locals stepped back a couple of metres, in line with social distancing. Ministers insisted that Mr Cummings had “stayed put” at his family property in Durham during his -day self-isolation period. But Robin Lees, , a retired chemistry teacher from Barnard Castle, claimed he saw Mr Cummings and his family walking by the River Tees in the town before getting into a car around lunch time on April . Although he may have completed his period of self-isolation, strict lockdown rules were still in place and the family were  miles from his parents’ home. Mr Lees said: “I was a bit gobsmacked to see him. They looked asthey’d been for a walk by the river. It didn’t seem right because I assumed he would be in London. “Of course he should resign now. You don’t take the virus from one part of the country to another. “It just beggars belief to think you could actually drive when the advice was stay home, save lives. It couldn’t have been clearer.”  When askedhe was going to consider resigning following the allegations, Mr Cummings said: “Obviously not.” The architect of the Vote Leave campaign added: “You guys are probably as right about that as you are about Brexit, remember how right you were ” When challenged by a reporter who said his decision to self-isolate in Durham “didn’t look good”, he said: “Who cares about good looks  It’s a question of doing the right thing. It’s not about what you guys think. A No  spokesman described the Mirroraposs story on Mr Cummings travelling to self-isolate in Durham as inaccurate - despite confirming it earlier in the day. They added: Today they are writing more inaccurate stories including claims that Mr Cummings ed to Durham after ing to work in Downing Street on  April. We will not waste our time answering a stream of  allegations about Mr Cummings from campaigning newspapers. Downing Street also denied Durham Police had spoken to Mr Cummings or his family, following their confirmation they had visited the property on March .  But the force has stood by their statement, and said “officers explained to the family the guidelines around self-isolation and reiterated the appropriate advice”. Mr Cummings’ father, Robert, , has also tried to claim the scandal was a “pack of lies” when telephoned by the Sunday Mirror yesterday. Durham’s Police and Crime Commissioner has said officers acted appropriately in visiting the property. A Durham Police spokesman said: “On Tuesday, March , our officers were made aware that Dominic Cummings had travelled from London to Durham and was present at an address in the city. “At the request of Mr Cummings’ father, an officer made contact the following morning by telephone. “During that conversation, Mr Cummings’ father confirmed that his son had travelled with his family from London to the North-East and was self-isolating in part of the property. “Durham Constabulary deemed that no further action was required. However, the officer did provide advice in relation to security issues.” And the PCC from neighbouring Northumbria has demanded the Prime Minister sack his chief adviser. Kim McGuinness said: “The Prime Minister should stop delaying, do the right thing and sack him.” Attorney General Suella Braverman breached all the usual conventions of senior Government law officers by defending Mr Cummings, suggesting he will escape prosecution.  On Twitter she said: “Protecting one’s family is what any good parent does. “The @DowningStreet statement claries the situation and it is wholly inappropriate to politicise it. But opposition parties said Mr Cummings must go. SNP Westminster Leader Ian Blackford said there seemed to have been a “cover up” over his whereabouts. Labour demanded that Cabinet Secretary Sir Mark Sedwill hold an urgent inquiry into Mr Cummings’ actions. Labour’s Rachel Reeves said: “The British people have made important and painful sacrices to support the national effort, including being away from family in times of need. “It is therefore vital that the Government can reassure the public that its most senior figures have been adhering to the same rules as everyone .”

story: NewsAll the lockdown restrictions that could be lted in next wave from June Since May  people in England have been given more freedom - so what will come in the next wave of coronavirus restrictions lted from June  ShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY NewsPeople enjoy the hot weather in Bournemouth, Dorset " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe are approaching week ten in lockdown, with many of us having spent even longer trying to avoid social interaction as coronavirus swept across the UK. It is clear that how weaposve been living canapost go on forever - and weaposre fast approaching the first of a series of deadlines where we might start to see ato something that looks a bit like normal. As part of the Governmentaposs -page blueprint, ministers  have set out a roadmap for how the lockdown in England might come to an end. Since May  youaposve been allowed to leave your house for an unlimited amount of exercise. But when will lockdown end and what could change from June   When will lockdown end  The answer is no one actually knows and hard-won progress in lting lockdown could be reversedthe virus starts to spread again. But Boris Johnson has reportedly told MPs he wants ato “near-normality” by July. Lockdown will only end once the government is satisfied it has complete control of the virusaposs spread around the UK. Which will likely mean a vaccine or effective treatment being in place. While some are hopeful that the Oxford vaccine trials will lead to results that could be seen as early in September, even Mr Johnson has warned that we may be living with this virus vaccineless for some time to come.  So what big changes are coming June   Well potentially very little. As while the Government has set out things it would like to change as early as June  it has said that when it actually gives permission for that to happen will be based on what the spread of the virus, or R rate, is in the community. Butthings go according to the draft timetable a number of big changes could happen.  Could schools re-open for more children  If the Government gets its way then yes. Boris Johnsonaposs plan is for Englandaposs primary schools to widen the number of pupils they are taking at the earliest by June  – after half term. The plan will see classrooms reopen in stages, beginning with reception, Year  and Year . Years  to  wouldlater in June. But teaching unions are demanding more detail about the science behind reopening schools. And headteachers have warned that many donapost believe their schools can be safely socially distanced. More than two dozen councils with more than , primary schools between them have warned they may not reopen on June . And the government has admitted schools wonapost open in a unorm way across the country. Soyou are in any doubt, you should check in with your childaposs schools about their plans. Secondary pupils in years  and , could go back in some limited form a few weeks later, but secondary schools are not expected to open fully until September.  Will shops reopen on June   Some will, some wonapost. The Government has announced that the phasedof non-essential stores will come around this time. But what will reopen will depend on the size of the establishment - can they make social distancing work safely  Weaposre expecting guidance closer to the time about which businesses will be covered in this section. However, the government has suggested it wonapost include hospitality venues such as pubs, restaurants and cafes - theyaposre only due from July  at the very earliest. From the coronavirus to Brexit, this is an era of great change and uncertainty. Events in Parliament have rarely been so crucial - or confusing. Our daily politics newsletter is there at .am to guide you through these turbulent times. Written by the Mirroraposs Head of Politics Jason Beattie it includes sharply-written commentary, a concise overview of events in Westminster and a sprinkling of gossip. Thereaposs then a .pm bullet-point update with the dayaposs headlines. Donapost miss a thing - sign up for the Mirror Politics newsletter by visiting www.mirror email. From around June  sporting and cultural events could take place again behind closed doors. In reality weaposre looking at around mid-June for theof the Premier League,talks with the government and operators are successful. Armchair football fans without Sky or BT Sport could be able to watch some live Premier League matches on free-to-air TV. Broadcasters have previously been banned from screening matches kicking off at pm on Saturdays amid fears fans would opt to stay in and watch TV rather than attend a game. But with matches due to take place behind closed doors when the season resumes amid the coronavirus pandemic, there is no longer a reason for the protection.  What about cafes and restaurants  Cafes and restaurants and other so-called higher-risk businesses and public places must remain closed until the beginning of July at the earliest, the latest official guidance says. They may be able to reopen slightly soonerthey have outside seating areas that can be properly distanced. But the vast majority will be closed for some time. And pubs and staycations  Despite earlier advice that pubs would have to wait longer than even restaurants and cafes, pubs were thrown a leline last week. Environment Secretary George Eustice said he wanted pubs to tentatively start gradually opening in July with social distancing in place.

title: teachers class act dunce critics
story: NewsopinionTeachers are a class act but their dunce critics deserve a political caningBoris Johnsons government is looking for scapegoats and the notion the UKs hardworking teachers, whose schools have never closed through this pandemic, are digging their heels in, is simply not trueShareCommentsByKeir Mudie:,  MAY NewsopinionBoris the Dunce is looking for scapegoats" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhat is it with teachers  Do they learn, at teacher college, how to deliver a telling-off  Or is it just experience  They’re so good at it. I’ve been ­interviewing teachers this week about schools and lockdown. And I made the mistake of asking one about when schools would ­“reopen” and they would go back to work. A killer pause. Then I was gently but firmly corrected. Schools haven’t closed. To say otherwise is an insult. Have you not done your homework  I tell you. In that instant I was ­transported back to Grimes Dyke Primary School, east Leeds, where I had to confess to Mrs Nancy Coverdale, the loveliest of all my teachers, that I hadn’t forgotten my swimming kit but hidden it in the cloakroom because I hated swimming. Still do. Those tellings-off were always ­justied. Like the one I got this week. This gentleman who I was clumsily ­interviewing was absolutely right. Schools have been open all the way through. Even teachers who are self-isolating have been grafting. It’s disingenuous to say the argument – whipped up by elements of the media spoiling for a row, and Boris Johnson and the Treasury looking for scapegoats – is about going back to work. Believe me, teachers desperately want schools back to normal but not when the risks are this high. They’re not sunning it or strolling round the garden centre. They’re ­working. My mum taught all her ­working le so I know about the hours, the terrible pressure, the impossible targets, the sheer workload. Anyone who thinks that job is finishing at pm, two weeks off at Easter and six in the summer is deluded. It’s often heartbreaking work. And it’s not just about lessons and marking. It’s making sure the kids are getting enough to eat. That they’re clothed properly. That they’re safe. It is a hell of a job. And very quietly they’ve been getting on with it.  But now we’re told they won’t go back to normal because the unions are digging their heels in. That’s just not true. They want to make sure we’re not rushing it. That no one, y’know, dies. Rightly, we won’t stand for anyone criticising the NHS frontline staff but teachers have been forgotten in all this. Forgotten. How can this happen  I can still remember all of mine. Mr Flanagan – who taught me Shakespeare and how to duck out of the way of a well-aimed textbook. The mysterious genius of Mrs Christine McLoughlin.

title: family launches first coronavirus legal
story: NewsFamily launches first coronavirus legal claim against care home after couples deathEXCLUSIVE: A family is to sue over the tragedy which they say was caused by a care home with little PPE failed to keep an elderly couple safeShareCommentsByDan Warburton:,  MAY NewsNorman and Shirley Milne both died of Covid- at Sherrell House Care Home " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe family of a couple who died of Covid- are preparing the UK’s first legal claim against a care home over the virus. Norman and Shirley Milne, both , passed away eight days apart. Relatives had installed a camera in Norman’s room at Sherrell House Care Home in Essex, which they say shows staff tending him without basic protective gear like masks and gloves. Son Steve Milne, , said: “Last week we had a double funeral for my parents. I feel numb, I don’t think it’s properly hit me yet. “I feel guilty because we put them in the home but we feel like the way they were cared for was either naive or negligent.” He has called in human rights lawyers and instructed them to fight for answers over the couple’s treatment. They are among an estimated , care home residents to die from the virus – a quarter of the national toll. Ministers have been blasted for failing to provide staff with testing and PPE – and their policy of releasing patients with the virus into care homes. Steve said: “The Government were slow to act and the message that was sent out from the start was that older people in care homes were expendable.” Norman and Shirley, who had dementia, moved to the care home in Chigwell last year from their house in nearby Buckhurst Hill. They had been married for  years and had six grandchildren. Former nursery boss Shirley was admitted to Harlow Hospital on April  a few days after showing symptoms and passed away four days later.  Norman, a retired electrical technician, was admitted there on April  but a test turned out to be negative. Despite medics’ warnings, he ed to the home. There Steve says his dad was served with an eviction notice because he had raised concerns about his care. The care home said it acted because there was a “breakdown in trust from the family”, they were receiving “persistent emails” and were aware of social media posts.  Hours after receiving the notice on April , Norman was rushed back to hospital.He died of Covid-, sepsis and kidney failure three days later.Steve claims that care home workers failed to use safe practices to protect his father from the virus despite his mother’s death days earlier. The family had installed a camera in his room – with the consent of the home – prior to the lockdown because of previous concerns about his care.  The motion-detected camera enabled relatives to watch live when anyone tended to Norman. They say they witnessed  incidents in  days where care home staff handled Norman without adequate PPE. Steve claims they gave his dad oral medication without gloves – despite the fact he was awaiting the results of a virus test and was symptomatic. Steve, a data analyst from Chingford, North-East London, said: “They’ve admitted that they didn’t use PPE on one occasion, but we’ve got video footage of dozens of occasions when they didn’t use it.”  He said one staff member told him  of the  residents had Covid symptoms at one point. “This was a private care home – we were paying £, a week for their care,” he said. “The blame lies solely at the feet of management, not inidual carers. “They were gambling with my father’s le. I want those responsible held accountable for what they have done.”  Last week  relatives attended the funeral of Shirley and Norman in Buckhurst Hill, ending in Manor Park Cemetery, in East London. Dad-of-one Steve – who has not been paid to speak to the Sunday People – said: “My mum was such a ray of sunshine, she was always so effervescent. As a couple they were so popular, so loved. “We couldn’t be there in their final days, that was taken away from us. This has devastated our close-knit family.”  The family’s solicitors Leigh Day say claims like Steve’s could be the “tip of the iceberg” as grieving loved ones consider action. Emma Jones, a human rights partner at the firm, said: “Norman and Shirley should have been protected from the virus but instead fell victim to the outbreak. It is essential that their family are given answers into what went wrong in their final days. “The only way people like the Milne family and thousands of others will get answers isthe Government agrees to hold a public inquiry or a full and thorough independent investigation.” Excelcare, which runs the home, admits a worker did not wear proper PPE on one occasion while aiding Norman. In a letter to Steve’s family it stated: “Having reviewed your video footage it is clear to see that the nurse who administered your father’s medication on the morning of the April  clearly did not use the required PPE or follow the safe administration of medication. This matter has resulted in disciplinary action.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA former Royal Marine who used to sunbathe on helipads slathered in cooking oil has been left with a huge hole in his nose from skin. Les Chadderton had no concerns over harmful UV rays and would happily allow himself to aposfryapos in his downtime in places like Singapore when he joined the military as a young man. But now the grandad-of-six is speaking out to warn others to take the dangers from UV rays more seriously after he says he had a wake up call with his cancer diagnosis.Les realised something was wrong after he noticed a spot on his nose which wouldn’t stop bleeding whenever he towel dried, reports the Daily Record.After a short, five minute consultation with a doctor at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary in February , Les was informed he had melanoma. Following a surgery to cut the tumour away in April , cancerous cells remained and so Les had to undergo a second operation to remove them – along with his entire nostril. The procedure, which was carried out in July , left a huge hole in the side of his nose that took months of painful healing. It slowly closed up but he bears a large scar and a misshapen nose from the ordeal. Les decided to share his shocking pictures in a bid to warn people about the importance of wearing adequate sun protection – especially as temperatures rise. Les, who moved from Greater Manchester to Aberdeen, described his ordeal as a “wake up call”. He said: When we were in Singapore and working offshore, Iaposd fall asleep on the helipad right in the sun.  Thataposs how much I thought about my body. I would just lay there and fry. It was crazy. I would come off a night sht when there were no more flights due in and grab some Kraft cooking oil from the galley and spread that on. I came from Greater Manchester and wasn’t used to that level of sun. But I just didnapost think of it back then. This has been a wake up call for me. Hopefully itaposs not too late in my le to have saved me. I look at le completely dferently now. You see a lot of young people on social media during lockdown and they just lie in their gardens all day. I want to emphasise to people now that yeah, itaposs alright to have a nice tan but what happens when it’s too late. Theyaposll try and blame everyone but themselves. Nobody is forcing them to lie in the sun for  hours a day. They take it for granted, like I did. I donapost want this to happen to anyone . I have to try and educate people as best I can. Les joined the  Commando Royal Marines when he was  and was stationed in Arbroath, but travelled all around the world including to Singapore, Malta and even Arctic training leaving him burned off the snow reflection . Les said: When I was in the forces, we couldnapost just buy the sun tan lotion in a shop that you can now.  We travelled the world and were always in the Sun but took no precautions. Even after leaving the Marines at , I didn’t pay any attention to protection from the sun. On holiday I would just walk around in shorts and a vest. Sometimes not even a vest. Sun tan lotion meant nothing to me. Whatever came out of the bag I’d put it on. If we were running out towards the end of the holiday Iaposd mix in some baby oil to make it last. When I look at it now, thataposs how ridiculous it got. That’s how I was caught out. It wasnapost until a spot appeared on his nose which would regularly bleed after being towel dried from a shower, that Les thought anything was wrong. Les said: I went to the dermatology department in Aberdeen Royal Infirmary and the consultant told me within five minutes that I had skin cancer.  I had to have an operation on my nose to cut away the cancerous cells. It was the same day as my youngest grandson, Laylan, was born. When I went back for a check up there were still cancerous cells so I had a second surgery, where they removed the bad tissue from both nostrils. I still have to get treatment to possibly reconstruct my nose and laser treatment. I’m not out of the woods yet. I got a blemish on my leg the other day and went to the doctors immediately. I went straight into panic mode. Les is now making it his mission to make sure people take as many precautions as possible in the sun, especially around his apartment in Tenere.  And he says his partner Dale White, , has already changed her own sunbathing habits after seeing the ordeal Les went through - and she ensures Les always has lotion on now. Les said: I see people who have been going there for  or  years and they tell me they’ve had problems with their skin and I ask them is it not a wake up call  People no matter their age - kids or adults - need to be educated about sun protection. There is only one outcome really and I’m proof of that. We took pictures of the operation and aftermath just to show how horric the results are. My whole outlook on the sun has changed completely. I didnapost care about the sun burning me at all, but suddenly you get this wake up call and you have to change your ways.

story: NewsGran, , weds Tunisian toyboy, , after friending him on Facebook by mistakeEXCLUSIVE Isabell Dibble sent a message to a barista named Bayram, and ended up marrying another man of the same name when she contacted the wrong oneShareCommentsByKate Pearson:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A grandmother of  has married a Tunisian toyboy  years her junior – after making him a Facebook friend in error.Isabell Dibble, , was searching social media for an airport barista who charmed her as she was ing from holiday in Mahdia. She had rejected his friend request after ing to the UK from holiday – then regretted it. So she sent a message intended for the barista named Bayram... but it went to Bayram Boussada,  – who she had never met. He is a cabbie... and the fluke contact led to a fare of the heart.  After months of internet chat, video calls and finally a face-to-face meeting, they married in Tunisia in January this year. Isabell – who has lost three husbands to illness – has no qualms about their age gap, saying: “I know there are so many cons that go on so I had my doubts and I was sceptical. “I read stories about women like this and I never thought I’d be in this position but he’s never asked me for money, he’s never asked me for anything. He doesn’t careI move there or he comes here, we just want to be together.” Bayram insists he is also head over heels in love and calls Isabell “my gorgeous woman, my soul”. Isabell, a receptionist, was single for four years when she took the trip to Tunisia. She says of her Facebook faux pas: “I added Bayram thinking we’d spoken in the coffee shop. I said ‘We met in the airport’. “He said I had the wrong person, but he still wanted to chat. We started talking and things went from there. “We literally spoke for hours and sometimes we were up till am on the phone. “I knew there was something there before we met face-to-face. “It was like we’d known each other our whole lives.”  The pair first made contact last May. Within months, Bayram started calling Isabell his we. She says: “I saidhe really wanted to marry, he’d have to ask properly. A week later he sent me pictures of a tray of rings and asked me to pick one.” Bayram invited Isabell, from Dymchurch, Kent, to visit him for a fortnight last October. She continues: “When I arrived I met his parents, who were incredible. They set up candles everywhere and got a cake and he proposed to me in front of them. But she adds: “After seeing their connection, I can see how genuine they are. He clearly loves my mum. After so much heartbreak, Isabell was as surprised as anyone to find herself falling in love – let alone tying the knot with Bayram at a register office in Mahdia, on Tunisia’s east coast. story: NewsMeghan Markles private diaries are ticking time bomb for the royal familyIt’s believed any memoirs of Meghan Markle’s years inside a monarchy rocked by a rt between William and Harry and Prince Andrew’s damning Epstein sex scandal links and damaging BBC interview could fetch up to million in a bidding warShareByGrace MacaskillRussell Myers:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMeghan Markle, , reportedly kept writing private diaries during her two tempestuous years inside the Royal Family after her marriage " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email As a young actress on the cusp of Hollywood fame, Meghan Markle wouldfrom long days on set and spill out her thoughts into a blog.She shared everything on her online diary The Tig – from her diet and exercise routine to advice on work and love.And three million Instagram fans, , Facebook and , Twitter followers all hung on The Suits star’s every word.Then Meghan met Harry – and The Firm closed around her love of keeping a diary. On royal aides’ advice, her social media was wiped clean in January , two months after the royal engagement. The Tig followed in April that year. But now it’s feared that The Tig was simply replaced – by a potential ticking time bomb. Because Meghan, , reportedly kept writing private diaries during her two tempestuous years inside the Royal Family after her marriage. And as a controversial biography of the renegade royal couple is released – allegedly with their co-operation – Palace sources think it could just be a taste of more explosive revelations. Meghan and Harry, , are desperate to earn a living outside the Royal Family.They have no royal subsidies and are said to be paying back £.million at £, a month over  years for renovations to Frogmore Cottage which was to be their Windsor home.The pair – now renting a £.million LA villa from a film producer pal – have already appeared at a star-studded private gala in Miami for the bank JP Morgan in February this year. And Meghan has ed to showbiz, voicing a Disney nature documentary released in March.  It’s believed any memoirs of Meghan’s years inside a monarchy rocked by a rt between William and Harry and Prince Andrew’s damning Epstein sex scandal links and damaging BBC interview could fetch up to million in a bidding war. One insider said: “The fact they may exist and could contain material to embarrass the Royal Family is enough to make anyone feel uncomfortable, even though right now there is no reason to believe she has plans to publish. “Meghan has always been a tremendous self-publicist. Her account of some of the more dficult times would worry everyone in the royal household.” Royal biographer Ingrid Seward believes the new biography – Finding Freedom: Harry and Meghan and the Making of a Modern Royal Family – could just be testing the water.  “My feeling is it won’t be nearly as revelatory as we think,” she said. “There might be a few titbits in it – but what would be the point in the Sussexes giving away too much in this book when Meghan could write her own story  “Michelle Obama got £million for her book deal, and Meghan could double or triple that. I think she’ll hang out to write her own – making the royal household far more nervous.” While some worry the diaries could fall into the wrong hands despite the couple’s new US £, security detail, for others, Princess Diana’s catastrophic marriage revelations in her interview with BBC’s Panorama still loom large. Meghan has often been compared to Harry’s mother because of her outspokenness and dislike of tradition. In a carefully choreographed interview during a royal tour of South Africa last October, Meghan told broadcaster Tom Bradby she was “existing, not living” under intense royal scrutiny, while Harry admitted he and his brother had “grown apart”.  When they announced they were quitting Britain in January, Bradby warned the couple could give a no-holds-barred interview, adding: “I don’t think it would be pretty.” Meghan may have written about her perceived rivalry with the Duchess of Cambridge, who allegedly fell out with the American when she shouted at her staff. And her own family problems are almost bound to be in her diaries – such as her devastation over dad Thomas not being at her wedding. Meghan is suing the Mail on Sunday for publishing extracts of a letter her estranged dad handed over to the newspaper. In it, she begged him to end his “painful attacks” on her “kind, patient” husband.  The strain first emerged when Thomas was exposed for staging paparazzi photos shortly before the wedding. From the moment she stepped into the Palace, Meghan rang alarm bells for staff. Sources have often claimed Meghan had no regard for stuffy royal protocol. The signs were subtle at first, from stepping out in public with bare legs to signing an autograph and showing Harry open displays of ­affection in public. At first, she seemed like the breath of fresh air the monarchy needed. But rumours emerged that “demanding” Meghan was sending staff am emails and caused her PA to quit in tears. Then came the wedding preparations furore. It’s said Meghan wanted air fresheners as th century St George’s Chapel smelled “musty” and that she was hurt when the Queen refused her first pick of a tiara from the royal collection.  All seemed forgotten the day they tied the knot. It was the fairytale ending the country wanted, but the magic was short-lived when her dad gave a TV interview claiming he had been shunned by his daughter. Meanwhile, as Meghan’s confidence grew, so did her disregard for The Establishment. After falling pregnant, she was determined to do things her own way, breaking a four-decade tradition of royals giving birth at the Lindo Wing of St Mary’s Hospital in London. The couple courted further controversy by refusing to reveal the names of baby Archie’s godparents. Then last Christmas they declined an invitation from the Queen to spend the festive season at Sandringham for a break in Canada. It was the beginning of the end.

The toll released in Mental Health Awareness week raises fresh questions over forces’ handling of conditions like post-traumatic stress disorder. The “snapshot” showed  incidents in January alone. Official Ministry of Defence statistics disclose that the troops who sought help had attempted to hang themselves, overdose or slash their wrists with a kne. But military mental health support groups say the figure is the “tip of the iceberg” and warn that many of those self-harming could attempt suicide. The figures mean that over  military personnel could attempt suicide or self-harmthe number of incidents continue at the same rate for the next  months. So far this year at least five soldiers are feared to have killed themselves. Freedom of Information figures show that  soldiers, seven members of the Royal Navy and eight personnel serving in the RAF attempted suicide or injured themselves in January alone. Female troops are also more than twice as likely to self-harm than male colleagues, MoD figures show.  One soldier who self-harmed, who asked not to be identied, said it helped him cope with stress, a fear of failure and letting down his colleagues. He said: “I’ve been doing it on and off for five years. I cut myself and burnt my arm with an iron – that wayanyone asks I can say it was an accident. “I know it’s a mental health issue and I should get help but I’m concerned it will have an impact on my career. “I’m a lance corporal in the infantry and I’d effectively be blacklisted. I’m not the only one who feels like this. We had a suicide on the base last year and the message sent down the line was that the inidual was weak and a liability. Jeff Williams, of Veterans United Against Suicide, said: “It is very likely the situation is worse than the figures show given that many cases will never be identied. Many soldiers and veterans who self-harm later take their own lives. It’s a major problem.” Former Royal Marine Simon Maryan, of charity Icarus, said: “We’ve seen an increase in serving personnel from across all services getting in touch with Icarus for help. “They all say they are afraid to speak to superiors as they will have a black mark placed on their career. Others said they have been bullied and belittled while struggling with depression, anxiety etc as a result of service.”

But step through the front door and you would think youaposd stepped back in time. Built in the s, the red brick house is a typical three-bed semi - but the way itaposs built it the only thing thataposs typical about this property. Each room is a colourful wander back through the past and filled from top to bottom with s chic and glamour. From the Tiki-inspired Polynesian cocktail bar to the Youngstown-style kitchen and the stunnin living room to impressive bedrooms, no room has been forgotten. Emma Edwards and Nigel Preston worked tirelessly to transform their home in the fashionable neighbourhood in south Manchester into a vintage dream. And when they decided to sell up two years ago to move somewhere bigger, they opened their front door so people could get a glimpse at the s paradise. Colour fills every, single room from the floral wallpaper to the zebra print rug. Fancy a drink after a long day at work  Just head to the bamboo bar for a swt cocktail.Unusual pieces of art from  years ago fill the home, including the coupleaposs pride - a flamongo statue. And the renovation stretch beyond the house, with Emma even transforming her back garden into a s wonderland, complete with a beach-themed decked seating area with a pond. The pink wallpaper is vintage and the American-style kitchen has been recreated to perfection. Emma and Nigel have made sure all their furniture fits in with their s theme, from sofas, to dining tables and bookcases to beds.Emma explained: Most of what we have done is cosmetic apart from the s Hawaiian wallpaper in the living room, which we got from the States. It was £ a roll. “The kitchen is based on a Youngstown American s kitchen but the units are all modern made to look retro. I imported Chevron handles to give it that look. “The house has still got the s stained glass windows. It would be easy to turn this back into a s semithat’s what you wanted.” Emmaaposs passion for all things retro when she started collected vintage fabrics and furniture.She has now turned it into her business and runs an online shop, Miss Bamboo. But she warned that anyone  who wanted to create her stunning look that it has become increasingly dficult over the years. Emma told the Manchester Evening News: I have bought and sold a lot of stuff over the years but when I was younger you could get a lot more things in the flea markets and charity shops.  All that mid century stuff is gone now. I find things at specialist vintage events, on Etsy and on American Ebay. I know some specialist dealers as well. It’s about having the eye for this style. “I was a teenager of the s and there were a lot of youth subcultures then. Everybody was into something - there was rockabilly, punk, goth.

Professor Adrian Hill, whose team at Oxford University are racing to develop a jab, had originally hoped their efforts would be proved successful by September. But the researchers have suffered a setback because as coronavirus infections plummet in the UK, they cannot be sure their inoculation works, thereports. The Oxford vaccine is one of eight around the world and just one in the UK which is currently being tested in humans. Earlier in the year, scientists said they were % confident it would be proved effective by the autumn, making it one of the most promising candidates in the world. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here It is widely believed that a vaccine is the only long-term way to stamp out Covid- and allow lockdown measures to be fully lted. However,the virus is not spreading in the community, volunteers who have had the jab cannot catch it and scientists will not knowthey have immunity. More than , people - including over s and --year-olds - have been enrolled in the second phase of the trial. However, as the UK emerges from the peak of its coronavirus epidemic, Prof Hill says he now expects just  of these volunteers to catch it. If fewer than  test positive, the results will be of limited use.“We’re in the bizarre position of wanting Covid to stay, at least for a little while. But cases are declining, Prof Hill told the . Tipped to be a aposfront runnerapos in the fight against Covid-, the UK government has pinned their hopes on the Oxford project, and has already agreed to pay for up to  million doses. Business Secretary Alok Sharma has also suggested thatproved to work, half of the UK population could be given the vaccine by autumn. Earlier this week, pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca announced a .bn deal with the US government to produce an additional  million doses. The team is now looking to move its trials to coronavirus hotspots overseas, where the deadly bug is still spreading. “The US government, the UK government, loads of charities and philanthropists are all saying we’ll pay to have it manufactured, before you finish the trial. I mean, itaposs a huge kind of vote of confidence in what weaposre doing. Itaposs really flattering,” Prof Hill continued. “But that doesnapost guarantee the result. It could be nothing or could be great or somewhere in between.

Researchers in Singapore have used complex modelling to determine the exact date that the crisis can be declared over in countries around the world. Using data-driven estimates, they say that by September  the deadly bug will no longer be present in Britain, the Daily Star reports. This puts the UK ahead of the US, which will not be free of coronavirus until November . However, Italy and Singapore are set to stamp out the disease first, where the crisis is expected to recede by August  and July  respectively. Meanwhile, a leading professor at Oxford University has forecast that the UKaposs declining death rates could reach the stage of no fatalities being recorded on some days by the end of June. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, read our liveblog here Reaching zero cases means that the UK will be able to move to Level One in the Governmentaposs new coronavirus alert system, which would mean no social distancing measures are required. The UK is currently at stage four in the alert system, meaning there is high transmission of Covid-. However, the Singapore University of Technology innovation lab says the prediction is uncertain and can change with time. The date is also vulnerable to new surges of infections caused by easing lockdown measures and people breaching the rules. A spokesman for The Singapore University of Technology said: The model and data are inaccurate to the complex, evolving, and heterogeneous realities of dferent countries.Predictions are uncertain by nature. Readers must take any predictions with caution. Over-optimism based on some predicted end dates is dangerous because it may loosen our disciplines and controls and cause the turnaround of the virus and infection, and must be avoided. Separate modelling carried out in Washington and in Oxford has predicted that the UK could first see a -hour period with zero deaths from coronavirus by June. However, it is expected that there will be sporadic up and downs for several weeks afterwards. Professor Carl Heneghan, of the Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine at Oxford University told The Sun: I think by the end of June weaposll be looking at the data and finding it dficult to find people with this illness,the current trends continue in the deaths. But we will continue to have these sporadic up and downs for about four to six weeks. It comes after the number of Covid- patients to die in the UK rose today by  to ,, although that rise is far lower than the daily death tolls of over , recorded in April.

story: NewsTeaching union boss say Boris doesnt understand schools or nature of childrenEXCLUSIVE: Mary Bousted, joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, insists parents should not send their children back to school until it is absolutely safe due to the Covid- pandemicShareCommentsByKeir MudieGrace Macaskill :,  MAY NewsNursery and primary pupils couldto classes from June  following the announcement of plans for a phased reopening of schools " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson does not understand schools or the nature of children, the head of Britain’s largest teaching union said. Mary Bousted, joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, insists parents should not send their children back to school until it is absolutely safe. She spoke out after the Government released evidence it used when creating its reopening timetable. It said the risk to pupils was “very small, but it is not zero”. She said the Government had “failed on every test” when it came to the way they had communicated with teachers.Ms Bousted added: “I can only think that’s happened because Boris Johnson and the Treasury, who I think are driving this, don’t understand schools.“They don’t understand how complex they are. They don’t understand the nature of children and social distancing.” She urged parents to weigh up the facts before sending their children back. And she told the Sunday Mirror: “If I was in that position, I’d be looking at the rate of infection in my region. Is it going up or down  “Then I’d look at the school’s plans. Is it going to be clean  Is there going to be social distancing  Will my child be safe and what will their learning experience be like  “Unless I could assure myself the science said it was safe and every precaution was being taken… no, my child wouldn’t be going back. “If those criteria were met I may consider it. If not, I wouldn’t.” More than , head teachers have signed an open letter to Gavin Williamson, urging the Education Secretary to reconsider.  His plan for a June  reopening would see some nursery children and others from Reception, Year One and Year Six go back. But with dozens of local authorities set to rebel and open schools later, pressure is on for a rethink.The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciessaid on Friday there were two conditions for schools to open – low levels of coronavirus in the community and a robust track and trace system.SAGE chairman Sir David King made clear the chances of those both being met by June  are “virtually nil”. Ms Bousted said a lack of clear Government guidance had left staff uncertain over rules around social distancing and PPE. She said: “One real concern is for teachers in special schools, where lots of children require intimate care and don’t understand social distancing. Staff should have masks, gowns and proper protective equipment as we know the virus is likely to transmit through bodily fluids. “We’ve been arguing that special schools must have good PPE in order to protect their staff.  “In other schools, the level of PPE will y because the science is changing all the time. But at the very least, schools needs to be thoroughly cleaned – and deeply “There must be hand sanitiser. And for those who want to wear masks, they should be available.” Ms Bousted gave Denmark as an example of a country where the government put measures in place for a safe reopening. And she compared it to the “completely inadequate” guidance here. She said: “They’ve made sure they have thought of everything. “In Denmark the government gave extra money for schools to have deep cleaning twice a day. If they have a tablet computer, it has to be wiped down between use. The toys have to be washed twice a day. “There’s a really intensive cleaning programme. In England, schools are cleaned one hour in the morning, an hour in the evening. “Where is the deep cleaning  This is absolutely crucial.  “Our schools have one sink for every  children. Where and how are we going to get children washing their hands  These practical things haven’t been thought through.” Ms Bousted hit back at reports that the issue was becoming political and insisted it was about safety. She added: “We want schools to reopen. We know how important education is. But health has to come first – children’s health, staff’s health and the community’s health.” Tory MP Tom Hunt accused unions of a “bizarre reverse class war”. He said: “From the heads I talk to, it’s the ones from poorer areas or with children at most need who are keenest to get back into class.” Teachersapos Views: aposI don’t see it is heroic for staff to be at riskapos Catherine Armistead, Skerton St Luke’s CE School, Lancaster - Head for seven years.  We are a one-form entry primary school with up to  pupils. All throughout we’ve been open for children of key workers and vulnerable children. The most children we’ve had in is  and social distancing has been challenging as they can’t help but gravitate together. I’ve got staff who really want to be in school but there are mixed messages from parents. Less than half are happy to send children back. A lot say they want their children tobecause they are under pressure to get back to work. Some parts of the media have this idea that it’s time for teachers to “step up and be heroes”. I don’t see how it’s heroic for my staff to be at risk. We’re having a training day on June  where we’ll decide with staff and governors what the way forward is. aposClasses re-opened as a babysitting serviceapos Chris Dyson, Parklands Primary School, Leeds - Head for six years.  Nobody wants everybody back in school more than me. When you walk down the corridors at the moment it’s a ghost town. But it has to be safe for the staff and for the children. As a headteacher,anything happened to my staff I would never recover from it. Everyone who is in the know is aware that June  is not going to happen. The R rate won’t be low enough. The Government are opening Reception, Year One and Year Six as a babysitting service just to get people out working. If they were serious they would be opening Year  and Year  because they have GCSEs and A-Levels. Look at the guidance – anyone who is in a supermarket should be in a facemask. But in schools, no masks needed. It doesn’t make sense. aposHow we were treated is insulting and scaryapos John Hayes, Gospel Oak Primary and Nursery School, North London - Head for eight years.  The staff have been phenomenal and it has been amazing to see them rise to this kind of challenge. The idea that this is about “going back to work” is insulting and demonstrates a total lack of understanding. We are desperate for the kids to be back here but the absolute responsibility of heads is to make sure that everyone is safe. And it’s really scary at the moment because we don’t have enough information. I’m frustrated by the lack of trust the Government has shown in us. They’ve totally failed to take us into their confidence. If they had spoken to us at the start of this and told us what they wanted to do – and why they wanted to do it – we could have helped them. We could have planned properly. Parentsapos Views - Will you send your children back  NO, it’s too dangerous for our boy Michelle Irwin, , from Hull, East Yorks, works in a children’s home and has a four-year-old son, Stanley, who is in Reception.  She said: “I think it’s too risky to send the kids back. It’s scary that adults and children can carry this virus without symptoms, and I’d worry about teachers getting it.“When they stopped school in March, Stanley was able to sit on the carpet with his friendsand hold their hands while they sang nursery rhymes, and that’s what school should be about. I don’t think he will understand the changes.”NO, my little girl is high-risk Former palliative care worker Laura Hawthorn, , from Stalham, Norfolk, has a five-year-old daughter, Amelia, who suffers from the rare kidney disease nephrotic syndrome, which puts her at greater risk of catching infections.  Laura said: “Just about every parent in the country needs a break right now but, to me, safety comes first and I think the children will be too close to each other at school. “If we are patient, we can possibly save more lives. I think the Government is moving way too quickly when it comes to schooling YES, butI hear it’s unsafe, she’s out PR consultant Emily Cleary, , from Buckinghamshire, has a son in Year  and a daughter in Reception.  The family’s decision to send her daughter back to school has been hard. But she said: “We have weighed everything up and she willon June , subject to anything changing in the meantime. “She’s ing because we believe that some sort of school routine will benefit her mental health. The second I hear anything that suggests she’s not safe, she will be straight home again and that will be that.” YES, our daughter needs her friends Brad Hyett, , CEO of a company called Phos is from Gerrards Cross, Bucks.  He hopes his four-year-old daughter Ruby willto nursery soon. He said: “Ruby needs interaction with other children – there’s only so much my we and I can teach her and she’s itching to see her friends and teachers face to face. “We strongly feel that the benefits of sending Ruby to school signicantly outweigh any risk. “And we don’t think we’re putting our health – or Ruby’s – in jeopardy.” YES, we’re happy with measures in place Stay-at-home mum Siobhan Patterson, from Rutland, East Mids, says she is going to send her five-year-old daughter Florence back to Year One classes and her two-year-old girl Olivia back to pre-school.  She said: “Where we live in Rutland has so few cases that we are comfortable to send our five-year-old daughter back. “We feel that the measures the school are putting in place will keep her as safe as possible. “I’ve enjoyed homeschooling, but I can’t replicate the school environment.” YES, but it’s a very personal choice Management consultant Claire Holt, , from Woking, Surrey, plans to send five-year-old son Rocky back to Reception and twins Axel and Hunter back to pre-school.

Many beaches across England stayed largely empty on Saturday as the weather helped keep people away amid warnings not to break coronavirus rules over the bank holiday weekend. But, for goodness sake, keep an eye on your kids.”  Police are also concerned about virus spread and have urged people to stay away from the Peak District until later in the year. And in Brighton, the council is restricting access to the beach. This week also saw large crowds on beaches in Southend, Essex. The Prime Minister’s official spokesman said on Friday: “All of the anecdotal evidence suggests that the vast majority of the public are still following the rules. “And by doing so are helping to save lives and we thank them for that. “We recognise the sacrices which the public are making but as we head into the long weekend we must all renew our efforts and continue to abide by the social distancing rules.” Meteorologist Simon Partridge, from the Met Office, predicted the best of the sun will arrive on bank holiday Monday. He said: “On Monday, the high pressure extends further, bringing with it plenty of fine, dry, sunny, weather across the UK with some light winds. Temperatures in South East could be C.”

story: NewsopinionVoice of the People: Dominic Cummingss departure is long overdueThe Prime Ministers aide has shown a disdain for the guidance he himself put in place, and contempt for anyone who questions his actionsShareCommentsBySunday People:,  MAY NewsopinionHe travelled more than  miles in a car with his we Mary despite lockdown restrictions " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDominic Cummings has flouted one of the most basic principles of the way we are governed. There can never be one rule for a powerful elite and another for the rest of us. By travelling with his family from their London home to his parents’ farm in Durham during lockdown, the Prime Minister’s closest and most influential adviser has undermined that. While millions of families made sacrices in isolation, denying themselves contact with loved ones in desperate times, Cummings decided it was acceptable for him to ignore his Government’s own guidelines. He claims it was reasonable, legal and in the best interests of his young son. The public will be sympathetic but sceptical. Whether or not it was technically within the limits of the law, as Cummings says in his defence, is not as important as the message that the revelation sends to the rest of us – who obeyed the rules for the benefit of all. That he and Downing Street attempted to keep the trip a secret shows that he and Boris Johnson knew his behaviour was unacceptable.  His defence is shallow. Dominic Cummings has cast a dark shadow over the way this Government works. His influence, not least over the coronavirus, has been questionable. Now he has been shown to have disdain not just for the conventions of public conduct, but for the rest of society. His time in Downing Street has been short but his departure is long overdue.
